title: Why Culture Matters
description: This course is an introduction to culture, with an aim to broaden students' understanding of humanities in general as well as the relevance of culture to contemporary society. The course explores the relationships among cultural appreciation, cultural representation, cultural continuity and cultural criticism; it also examines how related knowledge and practices in the humanities are valuable of enriching, on the one hand, students' own value system and lifestyle, and, on the other hand, the overall betterment of society, particularly in the digital age of globalization. The course is not theory-based, but its purpose is to expose the students to the diverse strains of cultural thought and practice that are relevant to contemporary society, particularly that of Hong Kong, China and Asia. Relevant contemporary issues will be drawn extensively to explain the values of the humanities and the need for knowledge of cultural studies in the societies of Hong Kong, China and Asia.The course covers four sections to explain the breadth of knowledge that can be applied to understand how culture works. The four sections include (1) basic introduction of cultural studies as an interdisciplinary field, (2) media representation in popular culture, (3) memory, history and modernity and (4) community, urban culture and critical pedagogy. The four sections show the trajectory of applying a cultural studies point of view to understand why culture matters in today’s fast changing world. The Chinese and English sections of the course will select from a total of 22 sub-themes to discuss the role of culture to art, technology, education and humanities.
outcome: • Students will understand that culture is important in the building of a better society.• They will also gain the ability in critically analyzing the diversity of values and interests in society.• Students will be able to draw on a number of disciplinary origins within areas of the arts, humanities, and social sciences to appreciate the richness and the usefulness of interdisciplinary approach.• Students will gain a critical respect for local histories, traditions, and appreciate the value of culture in humanities.

title: Introduction to Public Humanities
description: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and practices of public humanities, an emerging field that examines the influence of the humanities in the public sphere. It guides students through the ways in which humanistic thinking and inquiry can impact community engagement, collective cultural history and memory, policy-making, and the cultivation of empathy. Organized into three sections—Visions, Paths, and Experiments—each part focusing on different dimensions of public humanities, the course begins by exploring the conceptual foundations of public humanism, emphasizing the importance of curiosity, generosity, and collaboration. As the course progresses, students engage with real-world case studies that demonstrate how humanities initiatives can reshape culture and society. Students will also experiment with designing a small-scale collaborative project, which allows them to transform their public concerns and humanistic inquiries into concrete outcomes. These projects serve as a starting point for their further development within and beyond the programs of public humanities. The course is designed for students interested in leveraging the humanities to enrich public culture.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:  Analyze and Develop Public Humanities Projects:Evaluate and curate small-scale public humanities projects, understanding their impact on community engagement and public scholarship.  Communicate Scholarly Research Effectively:Utilize digital platforms to articulate complex ideas in a clear, accessible manner, effectively reaching and engaging diverse audiences.  Collaborate Effectively in Diverse Teams:Work collaboratively to integrate diverse perspectives, assess team dynamics critically, and manage project challenges efficiently.
syllabus: Part A: Visions Week 1: Rethinking the Humanities for a Better Future Students will be introduced to the development of the humanities, focusing on the challenges in universities and exploring new directions. Core readings: Wang Hui, “The Humanities in China: History and Challenges.” History of Humanities 5, no. 2 (2020): 309-331. Judith Butler, “The Public Futures of the Humanities,” Daedalus 151, no. 3 (2022): 40-53. Week 2: Being a Humanist: Learning to Be Curious Students will learn about the tradition of humanism, especially the role of curiosity in everyday life as a counter to instrumental logic. Core readings: Sōetsu Yanagi, “The Beauty of Miscellaneous Things,” in The Beauty of Everyday Things (London: Penguin, 2018), 27-57. Perry Zurn and Dani Bassett, “A New Vantage Point,” in Curious Minds: The Power of Connection (Cambridge: MIT Press, 2023), 1-18. Week 3: Being a Public Humanist: Learning to Be Collaborative Students will explore the importance of generosity and collaboration as a counter to solipsism and competition. Core readings: Kathleen Fitzpatrick, “Reading Together,” in Generous Thinking (Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press, 2021), 82-131. Patricia Leavy, “Methods for Working with Nonacademic Stakeholders, Teams, and Communities,” in Popularizing Scholarly Research (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2021), 1-11.  Part B: Paths Week 4: Looking Around Us Students will examine how public concerns are integral in shaping the environment and community. Core readings: Phillip Meuser, “How Architecture Supports Lives,” in Public Humanities in Architecture (Berlin: DOM Publisher, 2023) OR Julie Sze et al., “Stories from the Field: Public Engagement through the Environmental Humanities and Allied Disciplines.” Resilience: A Journal of the Environmental Humanities 5, no. 2 (2018): 49-73. Tutorial Case Study: Suzannie Leung, “Socially Engaged Arts: Luke Ching’s Practices for Hong Kong,” The International Journal of Social, Political and Community Agendas in the Arts 14, no. 4 (2019): 25-35. Week 5: Learning From the Past Students will explore how history and memory are shaped and maintained through scholarship with a public dimension. Core readings: David Graeber, “The Myth of Barter,” in Debt: The First 5000 Years (London: Penguin, 2012), 21-41. OR Simone Bohn and Pınar Melis Yelsalı Parmaksız “Researching Mothers in Public and Political Life,” in Mothers in Public and Political Life (Ontario: Demeter Press 2017) Tutorial Case Study: Constance Crompton, “SemantiQueer: Making Linked Data Worked for Public History.” In Schwan, Anne, and Tara Thomson, eds. The Palgrave Handbook of Digital and Public Humanities (Palgrave Macmillan, 2022), 89-104. Week 6: Enriching Public Policy Students will be introduced how humanists enrich the direction and quality of policymaking, especially through introducing alternative rhetoric, ideas, and styles. Core readings: Sarah Dillon and Claire Craig, “Introduction,” in Storylistening: Narrative Evidence and Public Reasoning (London: Routledge, 2021). OR Judy Segal. “Public Discourse and Public Policy: Some Ways that Metaphor Constrains Health (Care).” Journal of Medical Humanities 18, no. 4 (1997): 217-231. Tutorial Case Study: Doris Sommer, “From the Top: Government-Sponsored Creativity,” in The Work of Art in the World: Civic Agency and Public Humanities (Durham: Duke University Press, 2013). OR  Mara Cristina Caballero, “Academic Turns City (Bogotá, Columbia) into a Social Experiment,” The Harvard Gazette (2004, March 11) Week 7: Cultivating Empathy Students will be introduced to how the humanities can offer empathy to the public. Core readings: Susan Lanzoni, “Introduction,” in Empathy: A History (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2018). OR Xu Bin, “Introduction,” in The Politics of Compassion: The Sichuan Earthquake and Civic Engagement in China (Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2017). Tutorial Case Study Junxi Qian and Eric Florence, “Migrant Worker Museums in China: Public Cultures of Migrant Labour in State and Grassroots Initiatives,” in New Theoretical Dialogues on Migration in China (London: Routledge, 2023), 22-40. Week 8: Reading Week and Midterm Paper SubmissionThe midterm paper enables students to consolidate their learning from previous lectures, while also assisting them in completing their group projects and final papers. Students are required to engage with the course materials by addressing the following sections, with each section being approximately 300 words, for a total of no more than 1000 words:  What aspects of your everyday life spark your curiosity? (Week 2) Describe the roles and responsibilities you typically assume in a collaborative project, such as: Studying community and/or environment Conducting historical investigations Analyzing public policy Communicating with diverse groups in the public sphere. (Weeks 3 to 7) The use of ChatGPT is permitted. You must, however, explain how ChatGPT was utilized in the preparation of your midterm paper, including details of the prompts given to the AI and how its responses facilitated your work. Part C: Experiments: Curating a Small Humanistic Investigation for the Public Week 9: Finding, Reading, and Curating Scholarly Works Online Under the guidance of the instructor, students will collaborate to read and curate a humanistic investigation using recent academic journal articles on public issues such as: Environment and Sustainability Community and Inclusiveness Public Health and Aging Urban Development Labor Condition Mobility (e.g. Migration and Tourism) Inequality of Technology (e.g. Digital divide and AI debates) Other topics (after discussing with the instructor) Students will learn to interpret the latest research articles and curate them in an engaging direction for public consumption. The selected articles should be interdisciplinary, encompassing both humanities and non-humanities scholarly work, aimed at drawing public attention and enhancing public literacy and intelligence. The curated content will be refined in subsequent weeks and prepared for online publication on the social media account of the public humanities program. Core readings: Jamie Smith, “Undergraduate Research and the Public Humanities: Workable Futures.” Pedagogy 22, no. 1 (2022): 61-78. OR David Rowe, “The University as a ‘Giant Newsroom’: The Uses of Academic Knowledge Revisited,” Culture Unbound 9, no. 3 (2017): 228-239. Tutorial exercise: Students will be grouped and tasked with developing a tentative area or title for their project. Week 10: Impactful Stories on Digital Platforms, for Public Literacy Students will be introduced to various forms of presentations and platforms, including Public Books (https://www.publicbooks.org/), The Conversation (https://theconversation.com/global), AEON (aeon.co), Gushi (StoryStudio https://storystudio.tw/), and various new media and community newspapers. Students should refine their storytelling based on their previous humanistic investigations. Core readings: Jacob Burg, “Pedagogy of and for the Public: Imagining the Intersection of Public Humanities and Community Literacy.” Community Literacy Journal 14, no. 2 (2020): 130-137. OR Jefferson Pooley, “The Impact Platform.” Parameters (2017).    Tutorial exercise: Students will decide on the framing and strategies for publishing their work to the public and consider potential stakeholders with whom they can collaborate. Week 11: Consultation Week (Attendance required) Week 12 (and 13): Group Presentation  Students’ projects, as initial attempts in public humanities, will serve as references or prototypes for further exploration in other modules of the program. For example, a group focusing on public health in Hong Kong might develop their presentation into a humanities research project, public art project, independent film, YouTube video, etc. The skills for different cultural formats are expected to be acquired by students in other modules of the program. Individual final paper (1500 words): Each student is required to write a reflection paper on the group project in which they participated. The paper should include the following sections:  Improvement Opportunities: Discuss how the group project could be enhanced, including aspects such as theme, content, time management, and presentation style. Alternative Approaches: Describe other directions the project could have taken. Learning from Peers: Identify the best projects in the class and discuss the strengths that can be learned from them. Future Endeavors: Explain whether you are interested in continuing and revising this project or if you prefer to explore other topics for future projects.Utilizing ChatGPT: Describe how ChatGPT was used to assist in the writing of this paper.

title: Research Methods in Public Humanities
description: This course offers an overview of research methods in Public Humanities, and equips students with the essential research skills, cultural sensitivity, and critical perspectives required to navigate this dynamic landscape. Through an immersive exploratory journey on research methods, students will engage in pilot research for a collaborative hands-on project, embodying the driving ethos of this course: engagement, praxis, and reflexivity. In this endeavor, students will explore diverse qualitative and digital research methods for investigating, documenting, and sharing stories, histories, and other forms of cultural mediation for community engagement.This course is designed to foster an interactive and dialogic learning environment that cultivates peer collaboration and exchanges of insights. Building on the conceptual foundations laid in CURE1004 Introduction to Public Humanities, this course provides students with the practical skillset needed to unlock the transformative and empowering potential of humanities-based research that nurtures and nourishes the community.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: integrate the conceptual foundations of public humanities with practical research skills to design community-engaged projects; proficiently apply qualitative and digital research methods to document and disseminate community stories, histories, and cultural practices; develop effective communication and interpersonal skills to collaborate with each other and facilitate dialogic exchanges; and evaluate the ethical implications of a research, as well as demonstrate an understanding of the best practices in fostering community engagement and collaboration.
syllabus: Week 1   Do Meaningful Research: Making a DifferenceStudents will be introduced to the epistemology, methodology, and an overview of research methods in Public Humanities.Week 2   Think Out of the Box: Research TopicStudents will engage with themselves, academic literature, and understand the importance of contextualization. They will also engage with their peers to start designing a community-engaged research project.Week 3   Be Sensitive: Ethical Considerations in Doing ResearchStudents will develop cultural sensitivity in evaluating the ethical implications of their research project. They will work towards adopting the best practices with research ethics in mind.Week 4   Listen! Do an Interview, Learn from Lived StoriesStudents will learn the essentials of conducting interviews, focus groups, and ethnography for community engagement. They will design effective survey questions.Week 7   Be Observant & Reflexive & ImaginativeStudents will explore the art of observation as a research method. They will learn techniques for conducting systematic observations to better understand the community context and dynamics relevant to their projects. Students will practice being attentive observers and taking field notes.Week 8   Be Tech-savvy: Workshop on Data Visualisation and Digital Scholarship ResearchStudents will acquire the basic knowledge of digital research tools and data visualization techniques. They will lean how to use these for data collection, analysis, and visualization to support public scholarship and storytelling.Week 9   Reading Week/ FieldtripStudents will join an off-campus cultural tour to engage with the city and the local community.Week 10   Be Receptive: ConsultationStudents will discuss their project proposal drafts and share any challenges they are facing with the lecturer and/or tutors. They will receive feedback to improve their proposals.Weeks 11 & 12   Be Eloquent: PresentationsIn these two weeks, students will share the proposals for their community-engaged projects, backed by concrete pilot research data. They will also exchange insights and provide constructive feedback to their peers.Week 13   Be a Good Storyteller: Writing a Research PaperIn addition to communicating their research to broad public audiences, students will learn the essentials of writing a readable and impactful research paper.

title: Text and Image: a Critical Analysis
description: This course is aimed at the students beginning their encounter with theory, in which they will learn the fundamental components of cultural criticism in terms of textuality and contextuality. Here the " text" is broadly defined as cultural artifacts, which includes filmic image, literary and historical narratives, social and everyday life experiences as well as media representation. The course materials are selected to give the students the basic information and guide to understand the object, the purpose and the method for cultural criticism. Topics discussed include intertextuality, defamiliarization, dramatic monologue, metaphor and montage, narratives and space-time structure, psychoanalysis and stream of consciousness, reader-response criticism and genre studies.

title: Religion and Contemporary Life
description: Despite their long history, the influence of many great religions can still be recognized in our contemporary world. This course is designed to introduce students to this influence of religion in various aspects of our modern life. It will explore a variety of religious themes such as religious myth, symbol and practice, as well as current religious issues in ethics and politics. In order to illustrate the religious presence in our contemporary life, we shall examine these themes by looking at cases of films, activities and practices that can be easily seen in the world today. It is an introductory course and expects no prerequisite knowledge from students.
outcome: Knowledge outcomes 1. To become familiar with the basic themes of the field of religious studies  2. To develop an understanding of the key religious issues in the contemporary world 3. To be able to reflect on the relationship between religion and the human condition in the contemporary world 4. To be able to engage in analysis of religious phenomena, taking into account of the key themes and issues involved.  Attitude outcomes 1. To develop a critical yet sympathetic attitude in understanding religious phenomena. 2. To develop a sensitivity to religious dimension of human life.

title: The Study of Religion
description: This course introduces the various approaches (such as philosophical, sociological, anthropological, psychological) to the study of religion, and attempts to show how, by utilizing the fruits and methods of these approaches, the history of religions can become the discipline which has religion itself as a proper object of study. This course then focuses on the study of the chief elements of religious beliefs and practices. These will include the phenomenon of religious experiences, myths, symbols, rituals, prayer and beliefs.
outcome: Knowledge outcomes 1.To become familiar with the basic vocabulary of the field of religious studies  2.To develop an understanding of the theories of religion 3.To develop an understanding of the key issues in the study of religion 4.To be able to reflect on the relationship between religion and the human condition 5.To be able to engage in a critical analysis of religious phenomena by the key approaches, taking into account of the key issues involved.  Attitude outcomes 1.To develop a critical yet sympathetic attitude in understanding religious phenomena. 2.To develop a sensitivity to religious dimension of human life.
syllabus: 1) Course overview 2) Defining religion  3) The Field of Religious Studies 4) Sacred Power 5) Religious Experience 6) Sacred Space and Time 7) Evil and Theodicy 8) Human Existence and Destiny 9) Myth as Sacred Story 10) Ritual as Sacred Action 11) Religion and Morality 12) Institutionalized Religion 13) Conclusion

title: Chinese Culture and Its Religion
requirements: Not for students who have taken UGEC1450 or UGEA1450
description: (UGEA1450 is double-coded with CURE1122.)  The aim of this course is to help students understand the basic religious characteristics of Chinese culture and the relationship between religions and the daily life of Chinese people. It also helps students to appreciate the richness and diversity of the Chinese traditions and acquiring essential preparation for more advanced courses in the area of Chinese culture and religions. The course is divided under the familiar categories of Buddhism, Taoism, Confucianism, and Popular religion. These traditions are, by no means, discrete and mutually exclusive. It will be demonstrated that they overlap and interact with each other through a variety of confluences and conflicts. Students will also be introduced to some primary source of the Chinese traditions including both textual and fieldwork data.

title: World Religions
requirements: Not for students who have taken UGED1400.
description: (UGED1400 is double-coded with CURE1123.)   This course provides an introduction to some major religious traditions in the world from a phenomenological and historical point of view. Topics include Christianity, Judaism, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Daoism and Local religions etc.. Through the study of religion in different cultures, this course seeks to broaden students' horizons and widen their academic experience.

(2) Students will be able to develop their skills in cross-cultural understanding and intercultural literacy.   Attitude Outcomes (1) Students will be able to develop their ability to have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of religious traditions especially those one does not belong (2) Students will be able to develop their sensitivity to ultimate concern and religious dimension of human life

title: Study of Christianity
description: (UGED1520 is double-coded with CURE1124.)   The primary aim of this course is to provide students a broad and comprehensive understanding of the Christian faith through introducing its characteristics, traditions, history, scripture, theology and ethics. It helps students to analyse critically the various forms of Christianity and appreciate the richness of the Christian religion that exerts so great influences on human civilizations. Through interdisciplinary dialogues, this course also aims at helping students to see how the Christian faith understands and deals with problems, predicaments, political and ethical dilemmas of humanity.
outcome: Knowledge:   To achieve proper understanding of Christianity as a global phenomenon and some of the representative manifestations of Christianity in various local contexts.  To obtain a comprehensive knowledge of the major aspects of Christian faith, especially its views of the meaning of human life.  To have a basic understanding of the methodology involved in the multidisciplinary study of Christianity.   Skills:   To be able to use the analytical framework and hermeneutical tools for the academic studies of the religious phenomena related to Christianity.  To be capable of relating what have been leant from this course to some other academic disciplines.  To have the ability to reflect critically on one’s own cultural and / or religious tradition.   Attitudes:   To treasure the value of human life and be sensitive to the related ethical responsibilities.  To appreciate the diversity within particular cultural and / religious tradition.  To become more respectful to others’ religions, worldviews and values.

title: Interpretation of Art
description: Targeting at students with no prior knowledge of art history, this course introduces students to methodologies and theories currently used by art historians and curators to analyze and interpret works of art. The course covers a range of themes such as representation, expression, form, style, Formalism, Iconography, Marxism, Gender etc. Using modern and contemporary Chinese art as examples, the course will equip students with transferable and analytic skills, knowledge of modern and contemporary Chinese art, aesthetic sensibility, and theoretical literacy, encouraging them to apply these methods and knowledge to the study of visual art.
outcome: Demonstrate knowledge of the basic approaches and methodologies in art appreciation Understand of key issues of the visual arts in modern and contemporary China Demonstrate facility in research skills and familiarity with primary and secondary sources Demonstrate the ability to analyse critically works of art by adopting appropriate theories and methodologies
syllabus: Part IIntroduction to the language of visual art and formal elements, definition of art, and key concepts related to beauty in Chinese and European arts.Part IIIntroduction to the development of modern and contemporary Chinese art, ranging from the Republican period to the 21st  century, exploring a range of artistic practices, including ink painting, oil painting, sculptures, and installation and covering themes such as modernism, art institutions, and globalisationPart IIIIntroduction to the theories and methodologies currently used by art historians and curators to analyse and interpret works of art, including Formalism, Iconography, Biographical approach, Marxism and the Social history of art, Feminism, and Semiotics.

title: Introduction to Cultural Management
description: Cultural management is frequently perceived as a new terrain both for the acknowledgement of the role of culture in driving economic and social development, and for the dissemination of managerial thought to arrange and plan cultural entities, facilities and services. This course first aims to facilitate students’ understanding of the rising discipline of cultural management, which is embedded in the transformative understanding of culture and the on-going global movement that highlights culture-led development. Second, it introduces the managerial approach to cultural assets, initiates students’ understanding of the relationship between arts management and the market system and government policies, and imparts the preliminary knowledge for the management of the arts. Third, it displays a spectrum of major issues in cultural management, such as cultural policy, cultural organizations and institutions, venue management and event programming, heritage, conservation and cultural tourism and cultural creative industries. The breadth of the discipline as indicated allows students’exposure to the basic cultural management concepts and strategies.
outcome: In terms of knowledge enrichment, students are expected to achieve the understanding of the discipline of cultural management, including its objectives and values, its relationships with the transformative understanding of culture, the on-going global movement that celebrates culture-led development. Other major issues will also be covered. Students are expected to understand preliminarily the operation of art businesses and cultural organizations in connection to market values and government administrative systems. In terms of management training, students will learn practicalities such as cultural managerial principles, planning strategies and basic skills, issues, challenges and limitations specifically for the arts and cultural resources. Discussions are largely based in the local context, supplemented with overseas and Chinese cases, with an awareness of the variances across contexts.
syllabus: Part I. Cultural Management as a New Discipline  This part introduces the historical and disciplinary background of cultural management.   1. Understanding Culture: history and theory The first section presents an introduction to the course. As cultural management is embedded in the discourse of culture, this section explores the concept of culture and highlights the theoretical transition from the anthropological idea of culture as values and practices to the understanding of culture as a capital and resource. The emergence of the cultural economy concept will also be discussed.   2. Understanding the Discipline of Cultural Management  This section discusses the evolution of the discipline of cultural management over the past four decades, that is, from arts management, to cultural administration and management. It introduces the objectives of the discipline; the way that this discipline has been gradually accepted and subsequently widely practiced; and its closely related neighboring disciplines. It also discusses the professional role of cultural managers; their differences from artists and creative workers are highlighted.  3. Cultural Management in the Globalization of Culture-led Development This section examines the discipline of cultural management from the view of the global movement that utilizes culture as a driving force for development. It discusses a set of concepts that emerged in the recent decades, such as creative industries, creative classes, cultural planning, culture-led urban regeneration and creative cities. It provides the historical background for the evolution of these concepts, discusses the issues and challenges that they encounter and their application in various local contexts.   Part II. Managing the Arts Art management is considered a traditional realm of cultural management. This part focuses on the managerial approach to the arts. Section 4 investigates the disciplinary relationship between cultural management and traditional management, and the peculiarities of art management. Sections 5 and 6 introduce preliminarily the management of two major art sectors: performing arts and visual arts. Sections 7 and 8 are concerned with cultural management in the social environment and discuss its connections to art marketing and administration.   4. Managerial Approach to the Arts How to manage the arts? How is art management different from the traditional study of management? This section introduces the managerial approach to the arts. It explains the disciplinary relationship between cultural management and traditional management, and discusses how art management crystallizes the philosophy of both management and the arts. Art management covers four main managerial issues, namely, strategic management and planning, human resources management, finance and accounting and marketing and consumer behavior. The empirical implications of art management’s peculiarities are also discussed.   5. Introduction to Performing Arts Management  Performing arts is one of the major subjects in art management. This section introduces the concept of performing arts and its management. It discusses basic performing arts programming strategies and its relationship with theatres and other performing art venues. Some basic modes of organizing performing arts and performing art agencies are discussed.   6. Introduction to Visual Art Management  Visual art is another major subject in art management. This section introduces the concept of visual art and its management. It discusses various types of visual art spaces and agencies (e.g., museums and art galleries), introduces their similarities and differences in concepts, functions, operational modes, policies and evaluation modes.   7. Art Consumption and Art Marketing This section focuses on the concepts of art consumption and art marketing. It discusses the determinants of artistic values and the processes of creating and diffusing artistic values in the market. It covers the issues of art consumer behaviors, market prices, cultural business branding and positioning and art sponsorship, from both the consumption-and production-oriented perspectives.   8. Cultural Administrative Structure The government plays a significant role in cultural development. This section attempts to investigate government and public administration in cultural affairs, its administrative structure, patronage and state-based arts funding agencies. Some recent tendencies (e.g., corporatization of government entities in cultural affairs administration) will be examined withHong Kong as the major context for study. Cultural administrative structures in China, Taiwan and the U.S. as well as their institutional reforms will also be examined.  Part III. Major Issues in Cultural Management  This part introduces some major issues in the cultural management discipline, including cultural policies, cultural organizations and institutions, cultural venues and events programming, conservation, heritage and cultural tourism, as well as cultural and creative industries. It will introduce students to the concepts, operational principles and their management or planning strategies. Cases from various contexts will be studied.   9. Cultural Policies  This section introduces the definition of cultural policies and the process of cultural policy making. It presents a preliminary discussion regarding the way that cultural policies affect cultural development. Policy issues such as government subsidies, cultural industrialization tendency, government’s promotion of art values and cultural censorship will be addressed. Cultural policies from various contexts will be examined.  10. Cultural Organizations and Institutions This section categorizes art organizations based on their basic operational mechanisms. It models the growth of firms in the cultural field and describes the sequences and stages as well as determining factors. It also discusses the governing structure of cultural organizations (e.g., the board structure and its impact on organizational missions and strategies), cultural funding and patronage, volunteer management and management control systems. A global perspective is introduced for examining the connections between local and international cultural organizations.  11. Cultural Venues and Event Programming This section introduces the concept of cultural venues, facilities and districts as well as events planning and programming. Students will be introduced to the theoretical discussions regarding the role of cultural venues and events in cultural development and their functions in fostering local culture. It also introduces basic principles of and strategies for cultural venue planning and strategies for event programming,including cultural venue administration, public engagement, event promotion as well as public-private partnership.  12. Cultural Tourism and Heritage Management What are cultural tourism and cultural heritage? What is their significance and inter-relationship? This section defines and discusses their roles in culture-led urban regeneration. It also introduces the basic strategies for programming cultural tourism and explains the significance and methods of heritage conservation. The second half of this section introduces an integrative approach to cultural tourism and heritage management in order to develop cultural destinations, using European, American and Australian casesfor study.  13. Cultural and Creative Industries The last section will investigate the theory and practice of cultural and creative industries. It will examine the historical context in which the concepts of cultural and creative economy have arisen, its adoption as public policy from the UK and worldwide and its reception and development in Asia Pacific region. It will look at policies and strategies as proposed and developed by various countries in the region with particular emphasis on China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Singapore and evaluate the development in Hong Kong.

title: Cultural Policy and Development
description: The course is an introduction to the nature, functions and making of cultural policies. Making references to examples of local and international cultural polices, it studies the relationship between the making of cultural policy and the infrastructure of power, the ideological influences behind the making of cultural policy. It also studies the latest trends in cultural development and its relationship with policy-making, and the impacts on the development of arts and culture, with particular references to the local context. The course also includes a practical aspect of drafting and developing institutional policy as part of the studies in cultural management.
outcome: Students are expected to learn about how cultural policy is composed, its scope and structure, and the ideological components behind it within the context of the infrastructure of power, and to understand the impact of cultural policy in shaping the development of culture. The course also intends to equip students with the skills of drafting institutional cultural policy, which is essential for the development of a cultural institution.
syllabus: 1. General introduction This section gives an introduction to the various definitions of cultural policies, with discussion on its impacts on cultural development and its relationship with the social and political infrastructure.  2. Culture and Power  This section investigates how political, social and economic powers affect the outcome of artistic creation, both in terms of the formal artistic languages and the modes of production and mediation.  3. Historical Background  This section uses examples from Europe and the United States to trace historically how various modes of governance were introduced and study the political expectations and social values hidden behind these policies.  4. Globalization and Cultural policy  In the 21st Century, cultural industry is recognized as an important economic and social force. Large scale cultural projects are implemented all over the world to promote cultural tourism and creative industry. This section takes a critical look at this global trend and reviews its cultural and social impacts.  5. Cultural policy in Hong Kong This section informs students of the infrastructure for cultural development in Hong Kong, studies the history and development of the arts within the governmental structure, and traces the various stages in developing a cultural policy for Hong Kong.  6. Institutional Policy Cultural institutions usually have their own cultural policies to set their visions and objectives for their long term development. This section studies the various types of institutional policy, with an emphasis on helping students to learn to prepare an institutional policy paper.   7. The Ecology of Culture  This section investigates some of the core cultural values in contemporary society, with emphasis on the Hong Kong context. It also introduces an ecological approach to cultural development, and reviews the success and failure of the existing cultural policies within the public and private sectors.  8. Cultural Development and Operation in China  This section studies another model in which cultural development is strongly managed by the government. Taking Shanghai as example, students will study the process of organizing exhibitions in China and ideological thinking behind this bureaucratic system.  9. Language of the Bureaucrats  In Hong Kong, the government has tremendous influence on the ways arts and cultural programmes are implemented. This section investigates how the civil servant culture and the language they apply shape the content of the policy produced, and consequently affect the course of cultural development in Hong Kong. Case study: Culture Heritage Commission  10. West Kowloon Cultural District: Mega Cultural Project Focusing on the development of the West Kowloon Cultural District project, this section reviews the original proposal, public responses, and the subsequent reaction of the government, with the intention to investigate the governmental modes of thinking and strategies in actualizing cultural projects.  11. Alternative Space and Community Action  As a reaction against governmental dominancy in cultural development, different types of alternative cultural institutions and groups are formed. This section investigates the potential and limitation of various types of non-government run organizations. It also studies the strategies of community groups in working with and against the government in fighting for a more nurturing cultural environment. Case study: Hong Kong Arts Development Council, Para site Art Space  12. Cultural Policy and the Future of Cultural Development of Hong Kong  This section looks into the future cultural development of Hong Kong, its relationship with China and other regions, and discussion the problems and possibilities for positive development.  13. Review and Discussion

title: Introduction to Cultural Studies
description: Through examining texts, artistic forms and discursive practices that reflect and produce different cultures, students will take part in delineating the working definition(s), methodology and critical awareness of the subject. Concepts such as multiculturalism, diaspora, hybridity, globalism/localism, transnationalism will be discussed. Emphasis will be given to Hong Kong culture as a basic reference point in its contact and interaction with other cultures.

title: Cultural Studies of Space
description: This course will examine the subject of space from the cultural studies perspective. The objective is to understand how space as a cultural phenomenon relates to matters of ideology, social class, nationality, ethnicity and sexuality. The course will investigate the ways in which meaning about space is generated, disseminated and produced through various practices, beliefs and institutions, and how understanding of space is embedded in the political, economic, or social structures within a given culture. Examples of space making and manifestation will be taken from both Hong Kong and overseas.

title: Culture and Travel
description: There are two characteristics in culture: regional (space) and accumulative (time), and is the way to acquire various cultural experiences from different space and time. From the cultural perspective, there are different levels of travel: from "tourism" for pleasure, "travel" for different purposes, like study, works, business or military, to "journey" for life experience and eternal truth. This course aims to provide theoretical reflections and historical analysis on the relation between culture and travel, and in particular, the wide range of symbolisms of cultural experience of travel. It will be able to help students explore the process of crosscultural interactions as well as the knowledge of cross-cultural management in travel.
outcome: Students should gain a much more critical and reflective understanding of travel experience and its power implications to both the hosts and the guests. Students should be able to survey major social cultural theories on travels.  Students shall get to learn travel that is culturally innovative and socially responsible through the course’s fieldtrips.  Students shall learn to become a historically reflective and culturally sensitive traveler or responsible citizen when they travel around the world.

title: Introduction to Film and Screen Studies
description: This course focuses on the language and the basic theories of film/media. From formal, historical and theoretical approaches, students will learn how to analyze and critique the meaning behind the cinematic images; also, will learn to integrate one’s cinematic experience in terms of emotion and reason, and to develop one’s ability in film criticism writing. In the course of teaching, three aspects will be highlighted including the critical, functional and practical ones.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:  - identify, describe, and analyze the technical aspects of film as art.  - deeply analyze in diverse ways of critical thinking on film/media, such as the views of genre, auteurship, and spectatorship, and grasp the ways to utilize these different analytical frameworks for the writing of film criticism.

title: Celebrity, Stardom, and Hong Kong Popular Culture
description: (UGEC2245 is double-coded with CURE2007.) Celebrity culture is generally understood as a cult full of short-lived trends and inconsequential fan behaviour. We seldom consider, however, the powerful influence it has over our cultural identities. This course examines how the interplay between celebrity culture and the cultural industry shapes cultural identity with case studies from Hong Kong as the major scope of study. Starting with a brief history of Hong Kong celebrity culture from the 1980s to the present day, the course offers an entry point for students to understand the intricate relationship between the media and celebrity culture, encompassing a wide range of cultural icons and phenomena such as action film actors, cross-media megastars, and YouTube micro-celebrities. Each case study will engage with key concepts in celebrity culture, such as star-text, commodification, authenticity, extratextual reading, and participatory reading. The course proceeds by introducing the critical perspective of cultural studies in making sense of representation politics, public culture, fandom studies, and the diverse modes of intimacy in the digital age. Overall, students will gain an understanding of celebrity culture and how identities are thus produced, promoted, and commodified in the wider arena of media and popular culture.
outcome: Upon completion of the subject, students will be able to:  Define and explain the connotation of celebrity culture, stardom, and popular culture in contemporary society, and the genealogy of discourses development of Hong Kong popular culture over time.  Understand on how cultural identities are shaped by the interplay between celebrity culture and the popular culture industry.  Employ a selected range of methods to study the development and formation of celebrity culture and infer the meaning of such process in the Hong Kong context.  Reflect on the impact of celebrity culture on the formation of cultural identities.  Demonstrate the intersectionality of celebrity culture and the formation of cultural identities locally and globally.
syllabus: Class 1 Introduction: Why Does Celebrity Culture Matter?  Introducing the basics of celebrity culture and the importance of studying celebrity and stardom  Outlining the development timeline of Hong Kong celebrity culture from the 1980s to the 2020s   Class 2 Star Image and Star Text: Bruce Lee  Analysing the production and consumption of film stars and their star image   Synthesizing the critical concepts of ‘star-text’ in celebrity studies and ‘textual analysis’ in cultural studies  Assessing Bruce Lee as a star text in relation to the concept of ‘representation’  Integrating the case of Bruce Lee with the identity formation of Hong Kongers as modern citizens   Class 3 The Social Phenomenon of Stars: Leslie Cheung  Discussing the critical concept of ‘extratextual reading’ in celebrity studies  Assessing Leslie Cheung as a star text in relation to the concept of queer stardom and posthumous fame.  Integrating the case of Leslie Cheung with the identity formation of Hong Kongers as cosmopolitan   Class 4 Discussion Panel (I)   Students will work in groups to create a presentation about their favourite Hong Kong film star. Presentations should be submitted online via Blackboard.  Each group will then be assigned to review another group’s presentation. They will analyze the assigned work and apply one concept from Class 1-3 in their critique.   Class 5 Cross-media Megastar (1): Anita Mui   Interpreting the concept of ‘commodification’ in cultural studies in relation to Anita Mui's on-screen persona.  Demonstrating the influence of popular music on stardom and celebrity culture   Class 6 Cross-media Megastar (2): Twins   Theorizing ‘celebrity-commodity’ in celebrity studies and mapping the culture industry in the 2000s  Examining how the industry of popular culture in Hong Kong gives rise to cross-media megastars  Evaluating ways in which the stardom of the cross-media megastar influences the formation of Hong Kong cultural identity   Class 7 On the Politics of Authenticity: ‘Real’ Celebrity and Reality Shows  Discussing the concept of ‘authenticity’ in celebrity studies and media studies.  Critiquing how television channels have produced stars and singers via talent shows and reality shows from 2000s to 2010s  Comparing two local TV shows, Minutes to Fame (殘酷一叮) and Good Night Show – King Maker (全民造星) in their creation of ‘ordinary celebrities’   Class 8 Discussion Panel (II)   Students will work in groups to create a presentation about their favourite Hong Kong singer. Presentations should be submitted online via Blackboard.  Each group will then be assigned to review another group’s presentation. They will analyze the assigned work and apply one concept from Class 5-7 in their critique.   Class 9 Stars, Consumption, and Public Culture (1): Anthony Wong, Anson Lo, and Jeremy Lee  Discussing the concepts of ‘celebrity consumption’ and ‘participatory reading’  Examining the ‘campness’ of the star image of Anthony Wong, Anson Lo, and Jeremy Lee  Integrating the practice of ‘queer reading’ to complicate concepts of celebrity culture   Class 10 Stars, Consumption, and Public Culture (2): Denise Ho, Kay Tse, and Charmaine Fong  Demonstrating celebrity consumption as a fundamental part of public culture  Exploring how celebrities engage with fans in the public arena  Assessing the star text and fandom of Denise Ho, Kay Tse, and Charmaine Fong in relation to the identity formation of Hong Kongers from 2010s to 2020s.   Class 11 Stars in the Era of Platform Culture  Examining the availability of media platforms (e.g. Instagram, YouTube) and convergence media culture  Evaluating changes in the celebrity culture alongside convergence culture  Reflect on how convergence culture influences the formation of Hong Kong identity  Case study: Serrin/ Leung Ka-yan (梁嘉茵) and Trial & Error (試當真)   Class 12 Discussion Panel (III)  Students will work in groups to create a presentation about their favourite Hong Kong micro-celebrity. Presentations should be submitted online via Blackboard.  Each group will then be assigned to review another group’s presentation. They will analyze the assigned work and apply one concept from Class 9-11 in their critique.   Class 13 The Trans-Asian Influence of J-pop and K-pop Culture to Hong Kong  Evaluating the trans-Asian influence of J-pop and K-pop on Hong Kong celebrity culture in terms of industry, star images, and styles.  Case study: Cookies and Mirror

title: Understanding Digital Humanities
description: This course introduces students to theories and practices of digital humanities. The aim is to explore the technological shaping of human cultures through practices. Students will learn about the history, the rationale, the benefits, and the challenges of digital humanities. Each week, the lecture will introduce the historical trajectory of the fields’ development, its new configurations with the emergent technologies (such as Natural Language Processing and Language models). From week three onwards, each lecture will also include a short section focused on introducing a DH tool. Tutorials are dedicated times for students to put theories to work and to experiment with the DH tool of the week. By the end, students will have the skills to create, analyze, and critique digital humanities projects. Students will also learn to critique the field's practices and contributions. This course will explore the intersection of technology and culture and discover how students can shape the future of humanities research.

title: Body Politics and Representations
description: This course explores issues related to the representations of the human body in various cultural forms, including literature, cinema, drama, photography, advertisings, and medical discourses etc. We critically interrogate and examine the logic and implications of these representations through close textual and contextual studies. With the help of contemporary cultural theories, we engage in theoretical discussions about the complex issues related to the body, covering topics of identity, society, gender, and sexuality. The aim of the subject is to help students to understand the cultural myths and the rich meanings of the human body, so that we can most intimately examine the formation of our identity and value system.
outcome: Students are expected to understand how our cultural and social orders are made up of and maintained by representations of and various forms of discipline on human bodies. Students should be able to critically understand the many interests invested on the body, and critically evaluate the meanings of such diversity of values. With close studies of literary, film, and art texts, students are expected to develop literacy in visual and literary expressions. Reading theoretical texts from different disciplines, students are also expected to appreciate the richness and the usefulness of interdisciplinary approach

title: Meaning in Motion: Dance, Theater and Culture
description: Dance is historically entwined with many cultures around the world. Dance has certainly played a significant role of ceremony, rituals, celebrations and entertainment since before the birth of the earliest human civilizations. This course provides an understanding of the history, evolution, and universality of dance as an art form. Further, viewing dance as a social and cultural practice, the course aims at analyzing dance semantics and meanings in gestures, the interrelationship of dance and space, theatrical design and costumes, the formation of a dance to its social background, customs, as well as concepts of the self representation and embodiment in their dancing.  In particular, students will have opportunities to experience learning the gestures encoded symbolic meanings with narratives of dances. To demonstrate a physical understanding of a variety of dance forms, this course allows them to explore the pleasure of creative process of choreography in workshops.

title: Modernity and Urban Culture
description: (UGEC2042 is double-coded with CURE2016.)   This course is an introduction to the formation of modernity in relation to various aspects of urban culture. Tracing the development of cities and the urban cultures evolved within the new urban development since the 19th Century, cities such as Paris, London, New York will serve as 'texts' for analysis. Architecture, urban planning, artistic and intellectual movements as well as modes of everyday life in urban living are studied to demonstrate how the modern ways of thinking, seeing and living come into being. The course will also focus on the specificity of Hong Kong's experience in urban development and its adaptation of 'modernity' during a process of urbanization. The course will employ a wide range of visual images and audio-visual materials to explain the dynamism between modernity and urban culture.

title: Living in the Anthropocene: Nature, Culture and Power
description: (UGEC2243 is double-coded with CURE2018.)  Human have altered the environment in ways that have no precedence in human history. Ecological crisis, environmental degradation, and extreme weathers have become the watchwords of contemporary politics. The conventional boundaries between “nature” and “culture” are now being questioned. How do nature, culture and power intersect in our everyday life? How do we get to understand issues of sustainability and environmental crisis from a broad historical perspective and global activism angle? How are gender, class and race interact with technology, damaged environment, animal and plant species? This course explores these questions and the rich debates in the emerging field of environmental humanity and literature of the Anthropocene.Class topics are organized on major global green movements that resisted oil pollution, toxic factories, logging companies, dam constructions and nuclear plant building. Students get to learn the historical developments of major environmental activism in the West and the global south. How was the Greenpeace founded? What is the Narmada Dam Movement in India? Do you know Ken Saro-Wiwa, an environmental activist against Shell oil pollution in Nigeria? In each class we examine historical texts, visual materials and theoretical debates to explore how environmental justice has been intertwined with histories of colonialism, neoliberalism, and questions of gender, race, poverty and class. Together the class explores the problem of the Anthropocene (Nature) in the context of colonial history, grass root struggles (Culture) and corporation greed (Power).This course addresses many of the 17 United Nation Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs): Climate Actions (13), Life on Land (15), Life below Water (14), Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions (16), Clean Energy (7), Reduced Inequalities (10), and Gender Inequality (5). Students are able to identify the weekly course content aligned with specific SDGs and be able to understand these goals in both historical and contemporary contexts.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:  Acquire knowledge on major environmental struggles and movements in the West and the Global South  Comprehend the historical relationships between ecological crisis, colonialism and corporate politics  Analyze the current ecological crisis using the concept of slow violence  Evaluate the scientific debates of the Anthropocene with knowledge and analysis from the field of environmental humanities.  Acquire the awareness and contextual understandings of the United Station Sustainable Development Goals

title: Power, Identity, and Inequality in Medicine
description: This course is an introduction to the medical humanities, an interdisciplinary field of study that seeks to understand the social context of health and illness beyond the hospital, clinic, and laboratory. In particular, this course will emphasize the historical and cultural shaping of health disparities and examine how issues of power contribute to unequal patterns of risk and disease in our modern society. To do this, students will learn major theories and methods in the cultural study of health and medicine to understand how culture, power, and identity—including race, gender, capitalism, and colonialism— shapes the management of disease and individual illness experience in both Asian and global contexts. A critical concern in this course is how the organization of medical care confronts questions of social justice in medical treatment and public health in historical and contemporary contexts. Students will also grapple with the question of whether our institutions of medicine and public health function as a form of social control. By introducing students to the social components of health and illness, it aims to foster cross-disciplinary conversations across the faculties of arts, medicine, and other divisions at CUHK.Following the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goal of Reducing Inequality (SDG #10), a central question in this course is how medical treatments, research, and public health confront, or fail to confront, issues of social justice in global contexts. Students will learn theoretical approaches to health and inequality to investigate how history, culture, and politics shape the illness experience of socially marginalized people. These theories will enable students to assess the strengths and limits of our current arrangements of medical care and approaches to global health. In addition, students will learn critical medical humanities methods, such as ethnography, and use these methods to propose solutions to our current shortcomings in health governance. This course will challenge students to imagine better alternatives to our unequal world and demonstrate why the study of culture matters in medicine, global health, and public policy.
outcome: -Analyze how social inequality shapes disease outcomes (SDG #10)-Explain how media shapes public understandings of health and disease, including stigma-Situate individual illness experience in the social, political, and cultural contexts of disease-Implement the use of ethnography to develop health policies that can reduce inequality (SDG #10)
syllabus: Introduction: Critical Medical HumanitiesIn this introductory class, students will learn about the critical medical humanities as a method for interrogating fundamental questions of social justice in medicine: who gets sick, who gets better, and why? Students will be introduced to basic theories and concepts in the cultural studies of health and disease, such as stigma, biopolitics, and illness discourse, as tools for analyzing the complex social forces that shape health disparities. In addition, students will be provided with a basic introduction to public health systems, as well as information about the places and time periods that will be covered in the course. Unit One: Race and DiseaseThis unit starts with the histories of international disease control in Asian contexts, with emphasis on how social, cultural, and racial differences shaped the management of disease in colonial spaces. Students will analyze how issues of power and identity inform public health interventions, which often protects the privileged while stigmatizing and harming others. We will use the Hong Kong plague outbreak of 1894 as a case study in health inequity and learn, for example, about the homes of migrant Chinese labourers being burned by colonial officials in the name of disease control. We will conclude the unit by reflecting on how ideas of race and other forms social difference still shape the framing of disease even in contemporary discourses. Students will utilize cultural theories on race, gender, class, and inequality to identify how social biases shapes disease perception and response to reduce health inequality.1.  Difference and Disease in Tropical MedicineKey themes: hygienic modernity, power/knowledge, the “native” body, the laboratory in colonial discourse, vaccine politics2.  Colonial Tensions in Hong Kong’s Plague PandemicKey themes: race and space, epidemic orientalism, the politics of quarantine and sanitary regimes, germ theory vs. local knowledge 3.  Representing DiseaseKey themes: cultural representations of “the other” in disease discourse, endemicity as a cultural concept, body politics, the role of media in shaping disease response, global healthUnit Two: The Politics of Identity in Medicine Why are doctors often men? Why do doctors often come from socially dominant groups in terms of ethnicity and class privilege? What are the implications for how medicine is practiced? This unit offers answers to some of these questions by exploring the power structures that shape our institutions of medicine. We start with examining the social power of physicians. Students will learn about the social factors that shape how medical conditions come to be recognized, and the populations that are excluded or harmed in the pursuit of medical advancement. By understanding the politics of identity in medicine, students will gain the conceptual tools for understanding the health disparities that result when medicine often reflects the interests of socially dominant groups. Course discussions will invite students to apply concepts learned in this unit to address health disparities here in Hong Kong, where ethnic minorities representing 8.4% of the population face barriers in accessing care, mental health resources are not yet able to address demand, and a fragile public health system offers diminished care for the city’s neediest.4. Physician Power Key themes: medicalization, normal vs. pathological, social control, illness narrative5. Medical ExperimentationKey themes: medical mistrust, medical gaze, ethical variation, biopolitics, bare life 6. Gender and Medicine IKey themes: gender discrimination in medicine, bias in clinical research, androcentrism, experiential knowledge, situated knowledge7. Gender and Medicine IIKey themes: patient activism, advocacy, biosociality, online communities Unit Three: Medicine, Power, and Structural Violence In this final unit, we will connect individual illness experiences to the broader social, economic, and structural factors that result in ill health, such as poverty, uneven development, forced migration, and others. This unit will emphasize the illness experiences of marginalized social groups to examine the effects of social, political, and economic disenfranchisement on their bodies and health. By examining health and illness at the level of everyday life, students will develop an understanding of how ethnographic methods can be used to make interventions in health policy. In the concluding week, we will wrap up with a discussion about who benefits, and who may be harmed, in our current global health system and propose ways to align global health priorities with the principles health justice.8. title: Feminisms: Thoughts and Movements
description: (UGEC2273 is double-coded with CURE2022.)  A long-lasting struggle of gender equity was triggered by the women’s movements in England and U.S in the end of 19th century. Feminists fight for equality by publications, demonstrations and organizations. In 20th century, the feminist movement matured. Feminists have been more sensitive to the differences among women of different race, class, culture, religion and circumstances and noticed the importance of differences in unity. This course will introduce the strategies and main arguments of various kinds of feminism. Through learning from others’ experience, history and our daily life, we will understand the development of diversity in feminisms. We can have more understanding of feminists fighting for the right of disadvantage groups by self-review and mutual criticism in different times and culture.

title: Taiwan New Cinema and Beyond: Authorship, Transnationality, Historiography
description: This course aims to familiarise students with the key works of the Taiwan New Cinema movement and its legacy beyond Taiwan and into the twenty-first century. It will explore not just the work of a wide array of film directors, but also the texts and the condition of their production, distribution, exhibition and consumption within a transnational framework, all of which impinge on the question of “national” film historiography. It will examine, in particular: the socio-political background of the emergence of the Taiwan New Cinema movement, its key directors and their works, the international context of their reception and the transnational nature of their production, and its legacy to date. It will provide students with an in-depth knowledge of the work of selected film authors and an awareness of the cinematic, cultural, and socio-political contexts in which they work, and enable students to analyse the work in relation to questions of transnationality and historiography.

title: Contemporary Consumer Culture
description: This course surveys a wide range of topics on the commercialization of sports, tourism/leisure as an encounter of cultures/citizens/space, shopping mall and public sphere, and the impact on social and cultural life by the phenomenon of McDisneyization. Other topics such as advertising and pop culture, broadcasting (narrowcasting on the Net), merchandising and iconography in fashion will be examined to review key contemporary issues and debates about cultural consumption. Bringing together work on reception theory in literary studies and philosophy, studies on consumer culture in anthropology and sociology and those on media audiences within media studies, we will address the consequences and effects of increasing cultural commodifiaction and globalization, by exploring into the complex interactions of cultural production and consumption which are relevant in topics such as place and identity, visual culture and hyperreality, representation and communication technologies. Films and animations will be viewed outside class time. Field trips may be arranged.

title: Photographic Culture and Visual Communication
description: Photographs have tremendous power to communicate information; on the other hand, encoding and decoding metaphors of photographs present a unique set of challenges. This course can help students interpret and understand photographs meaningfully, later they can learn how to convey messages creatively. This course combines both the theoretical and hands-on approach to allow students to explore their creative visual expression and to learn the technical applications of the photographic medium such as camera basics, lighting and digital applications. It discusses the fundamentals of photography from the historical, cultural, aesthetical and technological perspectives. In particular, this course will cover aesthetical theories, social reflections, various genres of photography. To ensure that students be successful in their own personal and educational goals, they will be asked to create a digital portfolio on the Internet, as well as making selected photographic assignments of presentable quality.

title: Hong Kong Cinema
requirements:
CURE2030 is double-coded with UGEC2241.
Not for students who have taken UGEC2241 or 2774.
description: (UGEC2241 is double-coded with CURE2030.)  This course is a survey of Hong Kong cinema, with emphasis on its contemporary development. This course will cover both textual and contextual analyses: we treat Hong Kong cinema as an art form and introduce different ways to appreciate them and criticize them; we also read these films as commercial cultural products to investigate links between movies and society at-large. The course will introduce basic film theories and film languages. It helps students to reflect on their own relationship with these Hong Kong movies they grow up with, as well as help elucidate the complex relationship between Hong Kong cinema and Hong Kong identity.
outcome: Students are expected to acquire a general understanding of basic film languages, and to develop basic skill in film appreciation and film criticism. After the course students should be able to understand Hong Kong history and Hong Kong society from the perspective of cinema, with critical awareness of related issues pertaining to gender, class, and cultural identity. They are also expected to understand the intimate relationship between film production and film consumption, as well as the differences and connections between art and commerce in the domain of Hong Kong cinema.
syllabus: The lectures are organized historically, allowing students to gain a full picture of not only Hong Kong cinema’s history but also the history of Hong Kong. Students will also learn the basic techniques of film appreciation and film criticism through the various examples introduced. Lectures are composed of lecturer’s presentation and close analysis of selected film clips, through which students will be called attentions to specific stylistic, thematic, and theoretical issues. title: Understanding Visual Culture
description: This course introduces students how to understand and be critical of visual culture. We will study carefully and critically various forms of representations to the issues of paintings, illustrations, photography, films, television, and video games. We will learn the languages developed for these visual forms, and how ideologies are structured and conveyed through these visual depictions. In this visual age, while we are bombarded with more and more visual information and sensations, we are also effectively deskilled in our capacities as interpretive beings in critically engaging with these visual representations. This course teaches students how to appreciate the rich hermeneutic possibilities inherent in the visual culture and at the same time to be critical of ways that the viewers are rendered vulnerable to be manipulated by the visual images.

title: Youth and Popular Culture
description: This course studies the relationship between youth and popular culture, specifically in view of the rapidly expanding youth culture in recent years. We explore the importance of the factor of age in the study of popular culture, explaining why youths are vulnerable to the manipulation of popular culture, and why their lifestyles and values also dominate popular culture. We also examine how youth identity is constructed around the dynamics between mainstream identity and subcultural identity, and students are given the chance to analyse their own socio-cultural worlds in the various cultural environment, including home, school, concerts, shopping malls, youth magazines, and the cyber-space. This course provides students with an understanding of why youths, in particular, are prone to collective identity, and how they achieve their sense of self through fashion, music, sports, and entertainment.

title: Queer Theory and Culture
description: Queer Theories emerged in the 1990s as some of the most vital analytical tools in the fields of Gender Studies and Cultural Studies. This course offers students an opportunity to study this strand of critical thought in-depth. It will examine theories of queer from four major approaches, namely: historical, political, reading and performative. Topics of the course will cover a wide range of subjects including identities, sexualities, temporalities, homophobia, activism, deviance, and transgression. This course is particularly suited for students who would like to acquire the knowledge of a particular theoretical approach and to engage it in a critical examination of literature and culture today.
outcome: - To provide an introduction to the studies of queer studies - To situate local issues in the context of current intellectual debate such as identities, body politics, and sexuality; - To understand how literature, history, culture and politics are contingent upon their different theoretical and cultural contexts;

title: Cultural Policy
description: This course will introduce students to the historical and contemporary debate in Hong Kong and around the world on what constitutes culture and how governments and other organizations can help sustain cultural development. Particular emphasis will be placed on the context of Hong Kong and other cosmopolitan cities to examine how cultural policy can help shape a pluralist society. We will also discuss the challenges and distortion posed by economic and management criteria practised in today's capitalist societies to the intrinsic value of culture and the arts.

title: Trans-Asian Bodies and Visual Fantasy Cultures
description: This course analyses how Asian bodies and identities are represented in media and visual fantasy cultures such as Japanese animation, social networks, and performative subcultures. We explore how the extreme cultural and social diversity of the Asian region contributes to unique perspectives on bodies and identities. We are particularly interested in the studies of trans-Asian cultural flows, which includes not only commodities and entertainments but also migrations, like workers, and specific thoughts, like Maoism or human rights. We believe that a careful reading of these transnational flows would help us reconsider what Hong Kong culture and Chinese culture mean in contemporary bodies and indentity. We compare the cultural studies of local cultures with the discourses of trans-Asian studies and globalization, with the aim to demonstrate the possible ideological traps and strengths of taking Asia as an academic category for studying the body and culture.

title: Television Studies
description: This course aims to introduce the major studies of television understood as a set of institutions, technologies and texts shaped by historical, cultural, political and economic forces. This course examines television’s historical evolution; its relationship to other media; its preferred genres; its models of televisual spectatorship and consumption; its politics of representation in regard to class, race, gender, and sexuality; and its economic modes of operation. Upon completion of this subject, students are expected to understand the content and form of television as well as its industrial, social, cultural, and technological ramifications.
outcome: 1. Identify and analyze important concepts in television studies  2. Analyze and interpret television as a form of creative expression with regard to its multiple genres, means of delivery, and formal methods 3. Evaluate relevant aspects of television that not only reflect on society but also shape values and meanings 4. Articulate their understanding of television as a complex medium with industrial, social, cultural, and technological ramifications.
