title: Gender and Theatre
description: The course aims to introduce the perspectives in gendering theatre which is especially suitable for students who have interest in performing art and gender studies. We will discuss when theatre is constituted as a realistic reflection or fantastic world, what kinds of gender issues can be raised out? Any arguments that performers and audiences voice-out and act-out? What kinds of fantasy can be passed? Through analysing scripts and performances, we will focus on the cultural politics of artists and reader/audiences, so as to point out the relationship between gender politics and theatre.

title: Xiqu and Culture
description: (UGEC2294 is double-coded with CURE2042.)  The course introduces the student a basic knowledge of Xiqu (Chinese Opera), including its artistic features as a performing art, and the characteristics of different kinds of local Xiqu, such as Beijing Opera, Kunqu, Shanghai Opera and Cantonese Opera. Based on the basic knowledge of the art-form, we will discuss the cultural issues reflecting in the plays and performances. Through the textual analysis of scripts and performances, students will be introduced different topics of Xiqu related to cultural studies.

title: Performance Studies
description: Performances are actions, and "Performance Studies" is defined as interdisciplinary studies of human actions ranging from ritual, theatre, dance, music, popular entertainments as well as everyday life practice. The aim of this course is to provide the students with a knowledge of and insight into the key concepts, the historical development, and the socio-cultural implications of performance both in international scene and local context. Not only do we study the archives, the manifestations, the theory and the practice of various performers, composers, choreographers, actors, art and stage directors from different periods and traditions, but we also focus on the interpretation and communication, the audience reception and spectatorship of the social mass. It is a course draws on a wide variety of disciplines including social sciences, semiotics, speech-act theory, psychoanalysis, gender and queer studies, with which we can investigate the stylistic features, the quality of theatricality, the technical change, the hybridity and the boundary-crossing of performance in our era.
outcome: On successful completion of the course, you will be able to: 1.Understand the diversity and similarities of different Asian cultures from a cultural studies perspective 2.Understand the unique position of Asia in the current globalization discourse 3. Able to critically apply or interrogate Western based theories with specific Asian situations 4. Able to understand the relationship between cultural productions and social conditions 5.Gain a unique understanding of Hong Kong and China from the perspective of Asia

title: Understanding Comic Arts
description: (UGED2326 is double-coded with CURE2051.)   Nowadays comic strip has become one of the major forms of visual narratives in our culture. Both comics and film are visual arts originally developed within the period of late 19th century and early 20th century. Although film has long ago established its artistic legitimacy, comic art still struggle for recognition. However, as Will Eisner put it, comic strip is a “Sequential Art” and has its own unique aesthetic nature. This course tries to inquire the governing aesthetic principles of comics and investigate its unique method of expression. We will also try to delineate the special communication mode of comics and its relationship with different aspects of modern society and culture. Students will learn to appreciate comic art from different perspectives, and strengthen analytical skills for visual media.

title: Foundation of Visual Design
description: This practical class consists of lectures, readings, hands-on visual projects, and workshops, in which two main software will be taught: Adobe Photoshop and Adobe Premiere. Students will examine visual experiences from the perspectives of creators and viewers and will learn how to design images, edit videos, and add primary visual effects for their projects. At the same time, the practical work with these tools will help us better understand how they are used in society - the modes of thinking and inquiry they enable, their strengths and weaknesses.
outcome: - This course covers the basics of visual effects and post-production; students can use the tools as a creative medium in the context of contemporary art. - Apply essential skills and concepts in the development of critical and innovative design outcomes. - A broad overview of state of the art in new media art, critical design, and media theory.- Students will gain experiences from technologies and methods related to visual cultures and aesthetic functions in learning design. - Develop students’ aesthetic sensitivity and the ability of visual aesthetic judgment. - Enhance students’ portfolio for job seeking.

title: Myth, Symbol and Ritual
description: This course deals with the inter-relationship of myth, symbol and ritual, which are believed to play important part in human religious configuration. The human meaning of myth, symbol and ritual will be recovered in the context of social, cultural and psychological effects upon their believers. Meanwhile, theories and historical examples will be emphasized.

title: Philosophy of Religion
description: This course is a study of the nature and significance of religious experience and phenomena in human life and culture, the meaning of religious languages and concepts, and the justification of religious knowledge, particularly beliefs about God and man, in relation to various theories of reality and truth.
outcome: Knowledge Incomes: 1. Basic knowledge of the philosophical issues related to the religious phenomena; 2. Basic knowledge of major theories and schools of thought in Philosophy of Religion;  Skills Incomes: 1. Understanding, analyzing and criticizing an argument philosophically.  2. Articulating one’s own argument with consistency, coherence and persuasiveness;  Attitude Incomes: 1. Respect the differences among religions, worldviews, philosophical presuppositions and cultures.  2. Being reflexive and critical to one’s own position.

title: Sociology of Religion
description: An introduction to the scientific study of the social aspects of religion from the sociological point of view. This includes an exploration of the interaction between religion and culture; a survey of religion as a social institution; and an examination of the relationship between religion and other major social institutions.

title: Psychology of Religion
description: An examination of various aspects of religion from a psychological perspective. The contribution of such men as W. James, C. Jung and A. Maslow will be considered.
outcome: After completion of the course, students are able to: 1) demonstrate familiarity with the conceptual debates and controversies within the psychological study of religion.  2) identify key concepts in psychological studies of religious experiences and beliefs. 3) discuss how religion informs an individual's worldview and social behaviors. 4) apply important concepts, theories, and research findings from the course to study religious phenomena.
syllabus: Part I: Overview of the Field of Religion and Psychology 1) Introduction: Overview of the field of religion and psychology 2) Psychology of Religion: Classics and Contemporary (I) 3) Psychology of Religion: Classics and Contemporary (II)  Part II: Religion as a Meaning System in a Personal’s Live 4) Religion and Personality What kind of person would believe in God? Religious Orientations  5) Religion as a Call for Change: Cognitive and Affective Effects (I) Conversion, Varieties of Religion Experiences, and Mystical Experiences 6) Religion as a Call for Change: Cognitive and Affective Effects (II) Religiosity, Values, and Goal-Regulation; Christian, Taoist and Buddhist experiences  7) Field Trip (to be confirmed) 8) Religion, Death and Harming Fear of death and social behaviour; cults, violence, and religious terrorism  9) Religion and Well-Beings Coping, Adjustment Process, and Mental Health   Part III: Religion, Social Psychology and Society 10) Psychosocial Differences across Religions:  Religious Orientations, Religious Values and Social Behaviors 11) Religion as a Factor of Conflicts and Resolutions Social Class, In-group Bias, Prejudice, Helping and Parenting the spiritual realm  12) Religion and Forgiveness  13) The Future of the Psychology of Religion (Conclusion) - Guest lecture on spirituality, healing and empowerment 14) Reflection; Paper Submission

title: Hong Kong Taoism
description: The aim of this course is to explore the historical development of Taoism as a religion in Hong Kong. It will examine the historical link between Hong Kong Taoism and Taoism in traditional China, and will show how the activities of Hong Kong Taoism reflect the local religious characteristics of Hong Kong people.

title: Chinese Buddhist Classics
description: This course aims at developing students' ability to read a Chinese Buddhist text in depth. The first part of this course will be dedicated to a study of some recent models of textual studies in the field of Chinese Buddhism. The second part of this course will be devoted to an analysis of a text chosen from the Chinese Buddhist canon. The text will be studied critically through a historical analysis of the circumstances surrounding the creation and dissemination of the text. The choice of text will be based on the interest of the students but it will be chosen among some of the most representative traditions of Chinese Buddhism such as the Chan, the Tiantai, or the Huayen School of Buddhism.
outcome: To be able to understand religion in its historical settings and contemporary contexts of modern living; globally and locally and to analyze how contemporary religious expressions shape and are shaped by global and local cultural, social, and political trends.

title: Christianity and Western Literature
description: The purpose of this course is to expose students to the interactive relationship between Christianity and Western Literature. It may include literary works such as Augustine’s Confessions, Boethius’ Consolation of Philosophy, Abelard’s History of Calamities, Dante's Commedia, Shakespeare’s King Lear, Milton's Paradise Lost, Goethe’s Faust, Tolstoy’s The Kingdom of God is Within You, Dostoevsky’s The Brothers Karamazov, etc.; and focuses on the themes of creation, sin, fall, suffering, love, spirituality, redemption, purgatory, forgiveness, pride, peace, Kingdom of God, Nature, etc.

title: Introduct'n to Taoist Literature
description: The aim of this course is to introduce students to the Taoist literature in Chinese history. While there are many approaches to the understanding of the discipline of religion and literature, this course covers traditional Chinese literature in relation to Taoist thought, practice, institution, and symbolism. The focus is on the formation of literary genres as religious expression and transcendental imagination in the context, as much as possible, of the development of Taoist religion. This will allow us not only to realize literature as the principal record of Taoist tradition in its confirmation and valorization of Taoist values, but also to grapple with the literary challenge to inherited orthodoxies and thus the undermining of conventional ideas and feelings, as well as to sample the texture of literature functioning as an alternative or substitute for Taoism. In this way, we can approach the intersections of the aesthetic and the religious as the essential humanity through the reading and analysis of the Taoist dimensions of literature.

title: Religion and Ethics
description: An examination of the relationship of the Christian and various other world views to ethical issues of contemporary society.

title: Life and Death in Religions
description: Life and death are the central concerns in most religious traditions, which are usually transmitted through religious texts and rituals. Related themes include body, good life and good death, meaning of life, etc. This course will take a thematic approach to examine the issues related to life and death in major religions in the world, including the Chinese, Indian, and Abrahamic traditions. At the end of the course students should have gained a comprehensive understanding of the life-course models, the symbolism of death, the death rituals and the meaning of life in these major religious traditions.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: Understand the issues of life and death in major religions of the world in their historical settings and contemporary contexts;  Enhance their ability to have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of different religious traditions;  Engage in a critical analysis of religions from doctrinal, textual and ritual perspectives.

title: New Religious Movements
description: This course is designed to provide students tools and concepts with which to understand and study New Religious Movements (NRMs) and to promote religious tolerance. This course is divided into three parts: first of all, the significance and the methodological issues of New Religious Movements; secondly, some important issues on New Religious Movements, including rituals, gender, and economic dimension; third, Theoretical consideration and critique.

title: Foundational Medieval Latin
description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to Latin grammar and reading skills. Students will master fundamental structures including: noun declensions and cases, regular verb conjugations, adjective agreement, pronouns, and basic syntax. The course develops essential vocabulary and translation skills through carefully selected Latin readings of progressive difficulty.Through systematic study of grammar and syntax complemented by regular practice in translation, students will build the foundational competency needed for reading Latin texts. By the end of the course, students will be able to read adapted Latin passages, demonstrate command of basic grammatical structures, and be prepared for intermediate-level Latin study.

title: Beginning Sanskrit
description: Sanskrit is India's venerable and ancient language of learning, a key sustainer of 'high' culture and religion since at least 3000 years that continues today to be an important medium of religious, literary, and philosophical discourse. It is also of great importance in much Buddhist as well as Hindu texts, and factors importantly into several southeast Asian languages and cultures. This course will introduce the language, overviewing essential and intriguing features while providing basics in pronunciation, grammar, and vocabulary to appreciate its richness and expressiveness.

title: Religion, Health and Healing
description: Religious traditions contain particular understandings of body and mind, health and wholeness, illness and suffering, healing and transformation. This course will cover the latest discussion on the relationship among religion, health and healing. Also, it will explore the health/healing beliefs and practices in different religious traditions such as Taoism, Judaism, Christianity, Muslim, and New Age Movement, as well as will contrast those beliefs and practices with the hegemony of secular western biomedicine. The central goal of the course will bring students to understand how religious health/healing practices are constructed and experienced as meaningful in today's rapidly changing and globalized world.
outcome: After completion of the course, students are able to: 1) understand the ways that body and mind, health and wholeness, illness and suffering, healing and transformation are constructed in different religious traditions such as Taoism, Judaism, Christianity, Muslim, and New Age Movement. 2) understand the roles that religious practices can play in developing therapeutic understanding and facilitating effective healing process. 3) critically compare the health/healing beliefs and practices in religious traditions and in western biomedicine systems.  4) understand the importance of a holistic approach to health and healing.

title: Intermediate Seminar
description: This course bridges introductory material and senior seminar course. It aims to help students integrate knowledge and skills acquired in junior years and prepare themselves for senior study. It will review the major approaches to Religious Studies and examine examples of current scholarly research in the field. Students will learn techniques for planning, conducting, evaluating, and presenting research.
outcome: After completion of the course, students are able to:  1. Describe and explain the theoretical framework in the field of Religious Studies.  2. Identify and contrast different theories employed in the field.  3. Apply theoretical understanding to case studies.  4. Synthesize and evaluate key concerns in the field.  5. Analyze and assess scholarly materials in Religious Studies.
syllabus: 1. Major approaches to Religious Studies 2. Examples of current scholarly research in the field 3. Techniques for planning, conducting, evaluating, and presenting research

title: Special Topics in Religion and Culture
description: An opportunity for guided research and study of selected topics, such as: methodological approaches to the study of religion, theories of religion, folk religion, festivals, religion in transition in contemporary society, the Mother goddess, religion as salvation, ritual and sacrifice. The Special Topics will also be covering Religion and Culture, including:- Religion and Culture in Mesopotamia- Religion and Economic Life- Religion and Film- Religion and Gender Studies- Religion and Pluralistic Culture- Religion and Politics- Religions, Violence and Peace- Religious Education and Developmental Psychology- Religious Fundamentalism and Asian Cultures- Buddhist Art in Dunhuang- Any other topics related to Religion and CultureStudents are allowed to take this course not more than twice, and gain the units each time they pass the course.

title: Introduction to Buddhism
description: Buddhism has demonstrated a visible ability to adapt to changing cultures and regions for over 2,500 years. This course provides students with a general introduction to Buddhism. In this course, participants will investigate various thematic and specific aspects concerning the long and complex histories of Buddhism. Through the use of primary and secondary literature, film, and other media, this course will provide a regional overview of the development of Buddhism from ancient India to contemporary Western society. While we will try to follow the chronological development of Buddhism since antiquity, the focus of this course is more concerned with addressing key components that have shaped many different culturally specific Buddhist practices and doctrines. Course participants will be exposed to many of the unique philosophical, doctrinal, practical nuances and distinctions resulting from these cultural adaptations.
outcome: This course will enable course participants to:  Knowledge Outcomes (1)display adequate understanding of core Buddhist concepts and identify distinctions between various Buddhist practices, doctrines, and histories (2)demonstrate critical reflections on the relation between Buddhist teachings and worldly values  Attitude Outcomes (3)develop sensitivities and awareness of cross-cultural issues and begin to understand how they have shaped Buddhism into various modes of doctrines and practices (4)nurture a larger sensitivity to the value of Buddhist practice in human life  Skill Outcomes  (5)develop improved writing skills to better articulate the data/questions/issues extracted from course readings and discussions; (6)develop skills necessary for close textual readings and analysis of relevant materials.

title: Religion and Food
description: This course explores the intersection of beliefs/worldviews, health, and dietary practices in various religious traditions. Students will examine how different religious beliefs and customs shape the relationship between food and health within these traditions. The course will provide a comprehensive understanding of the impact of religious beliefs on dietary restrictions, rituals, and the overall well-being of individuals practicing these religions.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: Understand the beliefs and customs that influence food choices and restrictions in various religions. Understand the cultural and social aspects of food consumption within religious communities. Critically analyse the dietary practices of different religious traditions, including Judaism, Islam, Buddhism, Taoism, Christianity, and Hinduism. Critically analyse the role of food in expressing faith and spirituality within religious communities. Evaluate the impact of religious dietary practices on health and well-being. Apply the concept of fasting as a religious practice and its effects on physical and mental health.

title: Gender and Sexuality in Religions
description: Are religion and sex always at odds? How can religious aspects such as symbols, myths, taboos, rituals, and practices help us understand body, healing, medicine, gender fluidity, and sexual practices?Rather than simply dividing religions into different traditions, this course takes a thematic approach and examines religion, gender and sexuality as crucial systems of power that shape our world. Students will develop an understanding of religion and gender as both subjects and as categories of analysis. As categories of analysis, students will use gender and religion to interrogate cultural production and social systems, paying close attention to how gender and religion intersect with other categories of social difference. Students will connect the assigned academic readings to “real-life” examples in the news, media, and their own lives, thereby producing new theoretical understandings of gender, religion, and sexuality in the contexts of Hong Kong, Asia, and the world.

title: Intermediate Latin
requirements: Pre-requisites: CURE2154 or 2166 or 2167 or its equivalent
description: This course builds upon foundational Latin skills to develop students' proficiency in reading and analyzing Latin texts. Assuming basic Latin competency, we will advance through increasingly complex grammatical structures, with particular emphasis on: Middle and passive voices, Infinitive constructions, Subjunctive clauses and their sequence, Participial phrases and ablative absolute, Gerunds and gerundives, Complex relative clauses, Indirect discourse, and Conditional sentences.The course centers on intensive study of selected classical prose, primarily from Cicero and Seneca, supplemented by readings from other classical authors. These authors provide an excellent progression in syntactical complexity while offering varied prose styles. Through these readings, students will strengthen their command of advanced Latin grammar, expand their vocabulary, and develop sophisticated translation techniques. Special attention will be given to developing sight-reading skills and mastering complex syntactical structures. By the end of the course, students will be prepared to approach advanced Latin literature with greater confidence and analytical skill.

title: Latin for Law, Social Sciences and Humanities
description: Latin for Law, Social Sciences and Humanities introduces students to fundamental Latin language structures while focusing on terminology essential to social sciences, humanities, and legal studies. This course requires no prior knowledge of Latin and welcomes students from all academic backgrounds. While particularly relevant for those pursuing studies in law, social sciences, humanities, and related fields, the course provides all students with valuable insights into social, cultural, and legal concepts through the lens of Latin terminology.The course is structured in two complementary components. The first develops core Latin language competency, covering essential grammar including noun declensions, verb conjugations, and basic syntax. The second component applies this linguistic foundation to specialized vocabulary and concepts across disciplines, including philosophical terminology, psychological concepts, legal principles, sociological terms, and historical discourse. Students will learn to analyze and construct complex terms through understanding Latin roots, prefixes, and suffixes common in humanities and social science discourse. By course completion, students will be able to comprehend and correctly use Latin-derived terminology in academic and professional contexts, while acquiring sufficient Latin language foundation to pursue intermediate Latin studies if desired.

title: Latin for Science and Medicine
description: Latin for Science and Medicine introduces students to fundamental Latin language structures while focusing on scientific and medical terminology. This course requires no prior knowledge of Latin and welcomes students from all academic backgrounds. While particularly relevant for those pursuing studies in sciences, healthcare, and related fields, the course provides all students with valuable insights into scientific and medical concepts through the lens of Latin terminology.The course is structured in two complementary components. The first develops core Latin language competency, covering essential grammar including noun declensions, verb conjugations, and basic syntax. The second component applies this linguistic foundation to specialized vocabulary and concepts in scientific and medical fields, including biological taxonomy, anatomical terminology, pharmaceutical nomenclature, and scientific processes. Students will learn to analyze and construct complex technical terms through understanding Latin roots, prefixes, and suffixes common in scientific discourse. By course completion, students will be able to comprehend and correctly use Latin-derived terminology in scientific and medical contexts, while acquiring sufficient Latin language foundation to pursue intermediate Latin studies if desired.

title: Reading Religious Classics
description: The classics of different religions offer a wealth of insight and wisdom about nature, reality and life. Reading important religious classics is an essential way to acquire an in-depth understanding of the crucial doctrines and philosophy of a religion. This course gives students a chance to critically read classics, in their original languages or in translation, from one to two of the following religious traditions: Daoism, Buddhism, Christianity, Islam and Hinduism. The texts will be analyzed with a focus on their religious thoughts, and the traditions and skills of interpreting respective classics. Texts selected for reading may include Zhuangzi, The Heart Sutra, The Bible and The Quran, The Bhagavad Gītā, and religiously inspired literary classics such as The Divine Comedy and The Journey to the West. The exact choice of texts will be decided by the teacher who offers the course in a particular year.
outcome: At the end of the course, students should: 1.be able to read, understand and analyse samples of religious classics, with an awareness of the underlying cultural, social and historical contexts.  2.have reached a good awareness of the textual study of a specific religious tradition, and be familiar with the main relevant resources. 3.have acquired the basic linguistic and methodological skills to undertake independent research on religious texts, working on primary sources.  4.have improved basic academic skills, including critical reading, research, writing, and discussion skills.
syllabus: Course Structure  1. Notions of religious classics  2. The making of religious classics  3. Philosophical and doctrinal issues in religious classics  4. Traditions and skills of interpreting religious classics  5. Reading the religious classics in the light of its social, historical, cultural, and religious contexts 6. Critical reading of selected religious classics  7. Critical reading of selected religious classics 8. Critical reading of selected religious classics 9. Critical reading of selected religious classics 10. Critical reading of selected religious classics 11. Critical reading of selected religious classics 12. Critical reading of selected religious classics 13. Conclusion

title: Classical Arabic for Beginners I
requirements: Not for students who have taken CURE2151 (Arabic Beginners I)
description: With the study of designed texts and relevant passages from the Qur'an, this module introduces students to the fundamental grammar and syntax that both Classical and Modern Literary Arabic are commonly shared. Students are first introduced to the Arabic script, followed by the rudiments of Arabic grammar and syntax. To keep this course relevant and interesting, some Arabic phrases and dialogues in daily conversations will also be taught.
outcome: Upon the completion of this course, students are expected to:  The course provides ample opportunities to make considerable development towards the comprehension of the Arabic language in general and Qur'anic Arabic in particular. The graded introduction of Arabic grammar and syntax will intensify the understanding of the language and create confidence among students in a non-Arabic speaking environment. Student's skills are developed towards the comprehension of unvocalized Arabic text and translation of unseen Arabic text.
syllabus: The course covers the characteristics of Arabic scripts; the nature of noun including Idafah; personal pronoun and pronoun suffix; preposition and some special particles like Inna and Kana and its sisters; perfect and imperfect verbs and its derived forms, verbal noun including active and passive    participles; moods including the indicative, jussive and subjunctive; imperative and prohibition; sound and broken plurals; adverbs of time and place and numbers etc.

title: Introduction to Indian Religions
description: India among its one-billion population arguably represents the world's greatest diversity in religious and cultural thought, practice, and expression. This course aims to bring students in touch with the major religious traditions and cultural patterns of India. It also aims to awaken appreciation and understanding of how diverse peoples of India negotiate their lives within this complex religious and cultural landscape. The main question and thematic thread running through the course will be how the various traditions understand, express, and practice embodiment and transcendence. In other words, what are the constituents, changes, relationships, and possibilities for human beings and divinities with reference to the temporal world and transcendent reality? Where can we find significant "family resemblances" – without ignoring differences – among the diversities of persons and sub-traditions within those roughly designated Hindu, Jain, Buddhist, Muslim, Sikh, or Christian?

title: Introduction to Islam
description: This course aims to give students an understanding of Islam as a religion along with an insight into the crucial issues facing Muslims throughout the world today. The course introduces the beginnings of Islam by looking at pre-Islamic Mecca, the life of the prophet Muhammad, and the revelation of the Qur'an. The beliefs and practices of Muslims are explored through an indepth look at the five pillars of Islam. The variety of Islamic beliefs will be discussed in an investigation of Shi'i and Sufi traditions. The course concludes with contemporary issues of Islam in the world, interfaith connections, the place of women in Islam, and the presence of Muslims as political minorities in the West. In addition to this structure, local references to Islam in Hong Kong will be used to give an enhanced local perspective to these topics.
outcome: To be able to understand religion in its historical settings and contemporary contexts of modern living; globally and locally and to analyze how contemporary religious expressions shape and are shaped by global and local cultural, social, and political trends.  Ability to have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of religious traditions especially those one does not belong.
syllabus: 第一周: 跟同学见面，了解同学的水平及感兴趣的问题，以便备课。另外，介绍本课的授课方法及要求。  第二周: 伊斯兰的基本信仰 六大信仰： 信真主、信天使、信经典、信圣人、信后世、信前定。  第三周: 伊斯兰的基本功修 五桩天命：念、礼、斋、课、朝  第四周: 伊斯兰的主要特点： 一神论、入世性、全面性、科学性  第五周: 伊斯兰的禁忌和节日 行为的禁忌：举伴真主（以物配主）、伤害他人的生命和利益、撒谎、奸淫等。 饮食的禁忌：饮食的原则、清真的概念、不能饮食的物种。 穿着的禁忌：穿着的原则，“羞体”的概念和含义、男人的服装、女人的服装。  第六周: 伊斯兰的教派与学派 教派：笋尼派和什叶派 学派：哈乃非派、沙费埃派、马力克派和罕百里派。 中国的伊斯兰教派：格迪目、门宦、伊赫瓦尼、赛莱夫。  第七周: 伊斯兰的渊源：宗教的源头、“天启”的历史、《古兰经》与《圣经》、古兰经与圣训。  第八周:伊斯兰教与基督宗教的关系和异同 伊斯兰教-基督教-犹太教的关系、伊斯兰教与基督教的异同、伊斯兰教与天主教的异同。  第九周:伊斯兰与世界和平、穆斯林的人生理想、恐怖主义及其根源、伊斯兰的仁爱观  第十周: 伊斯兰教中妇女的社会地位、妇女的权利和义务、男女的平等问题。  第十一周: 伊斯兰与原教旨主义：原教旨主义的起源、原教旨主义的含义、原教旨主义的表现形式。  第十二周: 伊斯兰与贫穷落后：伊斯兰与商业经济、伊斯兰与教育、伊斯兰与科学、穆斯林落后的根源。  第十三周:伊斯兰文化面面观：文学、建筑、绘画、书法、哲学、医学、化学  第十四周:同学自己感兴趣的话题(开放)

title: Introduction to Taoism
description: This course aims at introducing Taoism as a Chinese religion embedded with ancient Chinese religious culture. Topics of the study will cover history of main Taoist sects, Taoist divinity, Taoist conceptions of immortality and life and death, Taoist ritual and Taoist canonization.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should have the knowledge to:  - understand basic concepts in Taoist Studies - understand the development of Taoism from the Han until contemporary period - understand Taoism in Hong Kong today
syllabus: 1) 道教研究﹕歷史、方法與困難 2) 什麼是道教：道教(哲學)、方仙道與道教的關係  3) 東漢天師道教團的形成及發展 4) 六朝江南道教(上)﹕葛洪《抱朴子內篇》的神仙思想 5) 六朝江南道教(下)﹕上清經(派)及靈寶經(派) 6) 唐代道教的發展﹕道教經典及道觀、道士制度的統一 7) 宋、明、清道教的發展﹕新興道派與全真道 8) 道教的神譜及宇宙觀 9) 道教的生死觀、救濟觀及倫理觀 10) 道教的齋醮科儀制度 11) 道藏的形成及源流 12) 近代道教﹕中國、香港及台灣的發展

title: Religious Traditions and Politics of the Arab World
description: The "Arab World" today refers to a large geographical area: from the Atlantic coast of North Africa in the West to the border of Iran in the East. Arabic is the principal spoken language of this region, which is also linked by shared cultural and religious traditions. The course presents a historical survey of the "Arab World" from pre-Islamic times to the modern era. The first part of this survey the rise and spread of Arab political rule and Arab language and culture with the advent of Islam in the 7th century, with later emphasis on some of the principal political, economic, social, religious, and cultural developments and their relevance to the contemporary "Middle East" region. Two main themes referred to throughout the course will be the unity and diversity of the "Arab World" and how various Arab cultures and societies have interacted with other peoples in this region and beyond.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:  Knowledge Outcomes Understand religion in its historical settings and contemporary contexts of modern living. Understand religion in its many facets. Engage in a critical analysis of religions by the methods of the humanities and social sciences especially through historiographical studies. Recognize central themes and issues in the Arab World, especially with respect to cultural and religious dimensions.  Skills Outcomes Communicate and present (orally and in writing). Gather, organize, deploy, synthesize and evaluate different types of evidence and information. Claim English proficiency in reading and writing with accurate referencing and clarity of expression. Demonstrate cross-cultural understanding and intercultural literacy.   Attitude Outcomes Have awareness of plurality and multi-faceted complexity within Arab cultural, political and religious traditions, and of the issues of multiple and conflicting interpretations of language and symbols, texts and traditions. Acknowledge the contested and provisional nature of knowledge and understanding. Show tolerance of diverse positions and have respect for others' views. Have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of religious and cultural traditions, political viewpoints and ideological positions, especially those one does not belong.

title: Chinese Temples and Festivals
description: (UGEC2500 is double-coded with CURE2375.)  This course is a study of Chinese temples and festivals. Temples are cultural heritages which preserve as mute testimony to local history. Their structures and the use of ornaments also reflect traditional architectural characteristics. "Jie dan" (festivals), including birthdays of the gods and jiao rituals, are the ritual activities being held for prosperity in folk culture. The belief system, indigenous custom, human diasporas as well as community cohesiveness of the Chinese can be illustrated from both temples and festivals in China and Hong Kong.
outcome: ¨          認識廟宇、節誕與民間文化的關係 ¨          通過廟宇、節誕實例，使同學了解香中國及港歷史與社會變遷 ¨          廟宇、節誕如何反映香港文物保育與文化遺產保存的工作 ¨          從廟宇看傳統建築與藝術雕飾的特色

title: Religions, Violence and Peace
description: Conflict seems a natural activity of human beings. It commonly results from contrasting ideas, perceptions or limited resources. It widely appears in diverse issues such as family ties, social justice, political ideologies or environmental concerns. This course is designed to provide students a process of (1) analyzing the assumptions, sources, and types of interpersonal, inter-group, and international conflict with the ideas of race, ethnicity, religion, and culture; (2) studying various forms of non-violent conflict resolution, and (3) studying both the relationships between religion and peace building.

title: Art Institutions in Twentieth-Century China
description: The course examines the correlation between art and institutions in twentieth-century China, aiming to encourage students to think about modern Chinese art through the concept of the artworld. The downfall of the Qing dynasty and the establishment of the Republican China transformed the social and institutional organisation of the production, distribution, and consumption of art as well as the traditional patronage system in modern China. The structural changes conditioned the emergence of formal and informal art institutions that facilitated yet constrained artistic practices, laying the foundation for the development of a modern art world in China. The course looks at the history of modern Chinese art and the formation of different art institutions in the sociocultural and economic context of modern China. Weekly topics are structured chronologically and thematically, which cover a wide range of themes, including art schools, art societies, museums, exhibitions, and art market. Adopting an interdisciplinary approach, the course offers students multi-perspectives to understand the transformation of modern Chinese art and the interactions between artistic practices and society in modern China.
outcome: • Explain the theory of the artworld and history of art institutions in modern China. • Identify and describe the historical background, aesthetics, and social factors reflected in specific artworks. • Identify and interpret the correlation between artistic styles and the institutional organisation. • Reflect upon the roles of art institutions in the process of art creation, production, distribution and consumption.  • Select research materials and develop original research topics on modern Chinese art.

title: Introduction to Heritage Management
requirements: Not for students who have taken CUMT2004, UGED2285.
description: Cultural heritage management presents a complex landscape influenced by globalization, urbanization, cultural place-making projects, technological advancements, economic development, and diverse applications in both the preservation of history and the creative industries. As cities expand and integrate globally, the challenge of preserving local cultural identities while balancing heritage conservation with modern urban needs becomes increasingly significant. In recent years, technological innovations and the development of smart cities have enhanced accessibility and supported cultural initiatives, transforming heritage preservation. However, issues of sustainability and resilience in dynamic urban environments worldwide have also emerged as critical topics and debates within cultural heritage management.This course aims to provide students with an introductory knowledge of cultural heritage management, along with the theoretical frameworks that shape our understanding of cultural heritage. It covers policy at international, national, and local levels, conservation and restoration practices, funding and resource management, and ethical considerations. While highlighting the significance of intangible cultural heritage, this course will also examine the impact of tourism and the vital role of community involvement, intersecting with issues of identity, technology, urban planning, and conflict. By offering a variety of foundational concepts and real-world case studies, students will gain a comprehensive understanding of current practices and challenges in cultural heritage management.

title: Management of Public and Non-profit Cultural Organization
description: Public and non-profit cultural organizations are positioned in the core part of traditional arts management education. This course aims to equip students with knowledge on the characteristics of public and non-profit cultural organizations as one type of cultural organizations, and mastery of the key management components of public and non-profit cultural organizations, including strategic planning, structural design, human resource management, leadership building, financial planning and fiscal management, marketing cultural products, and the organizations’ internal and external control and performance evaluation. A series of in-class exercises and individual and group projects is designed to develop students’ knowledge and management skills simultaneously.
outcome: In terms of knowledge, students are expected to gain an understanding of the specificities of public and non-profit cultural management, which are different from general management based on the understanding of the characteristics of those organizations and the profession. Students are also expected to achieve an overall picture of all the key components in non-profit cultural organization management. More emphasis, however, is placed on the students’ capacity to apply the knowledge of management to practice by enriching solid skills. Through this course, students can design the structure of a cultural organization, plan for strategies for organizational development, and enact internal and external controls. Their major final product will be a business plan for creating and managing a non-profit cultural organization. In addition, the students can acquire software technical training to develop portfolio design and job application skills.
syllabus: 1. Understanding Public and Non-profit Cultural Organizations and the Course Overview This introductory section provides a macroscopic view of the profession of arts management to illustrate what the business of arts and entertainment. The section also enumerates the sectors, explores the history of the profession, as well as provides students an initial understanding of cultural organization, the distinction between profit and non-profit cultural organization, and the common elements of cultural organizations. Furthermore, this section provides a synopsis of the structure of this course and other major issues.   2. Cultural Organization Typology and Functions of the Major Types of Non-profit Cultural Organizations This section discusses first the method for classifying cultural organizations and the characteristics of each type of cultural organization, which is the knowledge that has been introduced in the course of CUMT1001 “Introduction to Cultural Management.” Two major types of non-profit cultural organizations are then illustrated, namely, visual arts and performing arts organizations. Specific areas, organizational goals, and functions of visual and performing arts organizations are elaborated to illustrate the points. Tutorial: Conduct open-ended discussions about students’ perception of Hong Kong’s non-profit cultural organizations.  3. Management Thoughts and their Application to Arts Organizations In this section, management thoughts and theories integrated with scientific management are scanned with a review of early management practices and concepts along a historical timeline of disciplinary development. The application of management thoughts to the arts is discussed, with a distinction between general management and arts management. The contribution of arts management to general management at four key management components (i.e., strategic management, human resource management, finance and accounting, and marketing and consumer behavior studies) is also discussed. In addition, this section presents an open system approach to understanding a cultural organization, which interacts with the external environment. Museums and theaters are used as two cases to study the structure of a cultural organization. In the tutorial, students are taught to design the structure of an organization.  Tutorial: Design an open system structure of a cultural organization, Byrnes, 2009, 167-159. Assignment: Conduct small-scale research about a cultural organization (by interview or secondary data collection).  4. Creating Arts Organization I: Development of Arts Organizations What should an organization founder do and what are the strategies and approaches that should be considered in establishing an arts organization from scratch? This section determines the varied ways by which cultural organizations are established and organized. The external and internal factors that affect the structuring of cultural organizations and pending on the for-profit and not-for-profit nature of the businesses are discussed. Furthermore, this section introduces the concept of life cycle and evaluates its implication for the creation and development of cultural organizations. In addition to formal cultural organizations, the way to organize projects, including its phasing and matrix structuring, is also discussed. Tutorial: Discuss the ways by which a cultural organization is structured based on the students’ assignment in Lecture 3.  Assignment: Conduct a case study on cultural organization (by interview or secondary data collection) and compare it to the knowledge taught in class.  5. Creating Arts Organization II: Planning Strategies and Decision Making This section discusses planning and decision-making process and methods in cultural organizations. It also introduces a strategic planning process, which consists of the mission statement, mission analysis, vision statement, resource analysis, and the methods to formulate strategies. In addition, this section introduces a decision-making process by outlining the procedure of making choices and problem solving. These methods and processes are summarized with a sample of decision making and planning process. Examples of business plans and project plans are provided.  Tutorial: Discuss students’ designs of a cultural organization.  Assignment: Plan developing strategies for the organization and revise the organizational structure according to the strategies. Write Items 4, 5, and 7.1 for the business plan, Byrnes, 2009, 32–33.   6. Human Resource Management This section discusses the process of staffing a cultural organization, which comprises four steps. Step 1 is about conducting job analysis to determine the need for the positions and the major functions of jobs and specify duties and analyze the tasks. Step 2 describes and posts jobs. In Step 3, candidates are selected and recruited according to a set of due courses and criteria. Finally, job details and functions are reviewed and job trainings are provided in Step 4. Based on this lecture, additional advices about job hunting and application are provided. The second half of this lecture focuses on the issue of volunteer recruitment and management, such as discussing volunteer determinants, decisions to volunteers, and volunteer activities. A theater regarding a production team is shown.  Tutorial: Conduct an “in-design” software technical training.  Assignment 1: Write Items 7.2 and 7.3 in the business plan.  Assignment 2: Create a personal profile for job application.  7. Roles of Art Managers and Leadership in Cultural Organizations The career path and the professional profile of an art manager comprise another important factor that shapes cultural organizations. The first part of this section discusses the profile of arts managers, their personal mission, and their role in a cultural organization. The second part discusses power and leadership modes and outlines the mainstream theories of leadership and motivation. Dual leadership in museum management is particularly highlighted.  Tutorial: Conduct an in-class quiz.  8. Fiscal Management I: The Operations This section focuses on two important dimensions in organizational control system, namely, budgeting and financial planning. The budgeting process is explained with a categorization of budgets and detailed budgets. For the financial management in cultural organizations, pricing cultural products is discussed first to maximize the revenues and then the accounting system, after which other financial management issues are illustrated. Both museum and theater budgeting are used as examples.  Tutorial: Conduct class reviews and discussions about the quiz and the two assignments. Assignment 1: Write Item 8 in the business plan.   9. Fiscal Management II: Fundraising Strategies in Cultural Organizations This section introduces the methods used in raising funds for a cultural organization. Such methods teach students how to make fundraising plans as part of the strategic planning for cultural organizations. Afterwards, a series of fundraising skills is then introduced. The methods to control fundraising costs are also discussed. Fundraising in museums exemplifies the knowledge in discussion.  Tutorial: Discuss the fiscal plan.  10. Marketing and Arts I: Approaches and Strategies This section goes over the knowledge taught in CUMT 1001, including the shift in the concept of marketing from an inappropriate use of money to the essential selling-out of the cultural products of organizations, marketing theories, approaches, and processes geared toward developing the students’ understanding of cultural organization marketing. Then, the section explores the varied processes by which visual arts and performing arts organizations conduct marketing and discusses the key issues in their marketing processes, such as performing arts organizations’ market orientation and museums’ marketing strategies.  Tutorial: Conduct an in-class situation comedy, in which the topic is about fundraising or asking for money.  11. Marketing and Arts II: Market Research and Marketing Plan Making After the introduction of cultural organization marketing approaches and strategies, this section follows it up with a discussion of the practical methods to put cultural organization marketing in place. Two issues are highlighted in this section: (1) the exploration of cultural consumers’ behaviors and the modes for their attendance, and (2) the methods of conducting market research (including market orientation research) and conceptualizing marketing plans based on the characteristics of cultural consumers and the market. Marketing schemes of performing art organizations and museums are also studied.  Tutorial: Discuss marketing approaches and strategies. Assignment: Write Item 6 in the business plan.  12. Cultural Organization Performance Evaluation How can cultural organization management be controlled and how can we measure the performances of cultural organizations? This section discusses the controlling system of cultural organizations, including internal and external controls as well as performance evaluation mechanisms. A general model that is applicable to a variety of cultural organizations for performance evaluation is presented first. Then, the methods for evaluating the performances of museum and performing art organizations are discussed. The section also introduces for performing art organizations a qualitative model from the perspective of the audience’s experiences. In terms of museum performance measurement, the section provides an evaluation model that comprises a range of indicators, including validity, reliability, feasibility, and externality.  Tutorial: Discuss cultural organization performance evaluation. Assignment: Write Items 1 to 3, organize the materials for Item 9 in the business plan, and prepare the presentation for the group project.  13. Reviews and Discussions Students are expected to deliver their group outputs, consisting of business plans with all the required elements in Byrne, 2009, pp. 32–33s. A guest judge from the professional field, together with the professor, will provide comments on the students’ works. Finally, the key points of this course are summarized to prepare students for quiz 2.

title: Understanding Chinese Art through Exhibitions
description: (UGED2286 is double-coded with CURE2406.)  The exhibition has become a site of knowledge production and a prominent and diverse part of contemporary culture. Regarding “Chinese art” as a social constructed concept, the course uses “exhibition” as an entry point to engage with issues concerning Chinese art and to explore the role played by exhibitions in the formation of the knowledge of Chinese art. It introduces the current theories and debates on the theory and history of exhibition, and the display methods, examining the changing concept of Chinese art and curatorial practices through detailed analysis of case studies. The first part of the course traces the formation of the concept of “Chinese art” by looking closely at the history of exhibitions on Chinese objects from the late Qing dynasty to the early twentieth century. The second part examines important exhibitions that have shaped our understanding of Chinese art. Structured thematically, the course discusses the curatorial concepts of selective significant international exhibitions on Chinese art, and investigate how scholarly research has been transformed into exhibitions which have shaped our understanding of Chinese art, constructed identity and been deployed for political ends.
outcome: Upon the completion of the course, students will be able to:  ·      Explain the theories of exhibition and the changing concepts of Chinese art  ·      Identify and describe the important exhibitions on Chinese art and prominent Chinese art objects. ·      Identify and evaluate the curatorial ideas of important exhibitions on Chinese art. ·      Select research materials and Chinese art objects to develop original research. ·      Design and plan a virtual exhibition based on original research.

title: Curation in Arts and Culture
description: “Curating,” a word that was once only used in museums, now has applications in everything in our lives, ranging from radio station DJs to almost all types of social media content. The popularity of the word reflects the growing importance of assembling, managing and presenting data and collection, a process of gathering information that brings maximum value relevant to different audiences.In this context, this course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to learn about both historical and contemporary examples of how culture is understood through exhibition design and curating. By covering various forms of curatorial traditions, disruptive ideas, and emergent digital practices in the ever-expanding field of curation, this course equips students with the ability to question what they take for granted and reflect on existing issues conducive to different cultures, values and beliefs. By the end of the course, students will be able to critically examine how knowledge is created inside and outside of art institutions and how curation could potentially become public knowledge.
outcome: Upon completing this course, students will be able to: • Explain key historical and contemporary examples of exhibition design and curating, relating to a wider local and global context • Examine critical issues concerning ways that different cultures, values and beliefs are represented through curation • Develop skills to critically analyze how knowledge is created inside and outside art institutions • Acquire personal and social competencies to transfer curating into knowledge sharing and act as an active agent in facilitating knowledge engagement  • Develop an attitude of innovation and creativity by challenging assumptions in the ever-expanding field of curation

title: Introduction to the Art Market
description: The artworld is constructed through a network of individuals and institutions, all of which participate in con-tributing to the wider ecosystem of the global network and marketplace for art. The co-generative or mutu-ally constitutive nature between key players and institutions provides the context and rules for evaluating the aesthetic and economic value of art objects. In recent years, the art market has witnessed tremendous growth, and clusters of new galleries, global art fairs and auction houses have sprung up in cities within both developed and emerging economies, forming an ever-expanding network of art transitions, exhibi-tions, and causing an explosion of cultural activities amid various forms of urbanization. This course aims to provide students with theoretical knowledge and practical skills on how to identify the dynamic roles and activities of key players and institutions in the art market. It begins with an introduction to the history of art market, patronage system and art market logic. The, various practical skills are covered, including art valuation methods, techniques of buying and selling art, and agreements and laws that govern art transactions. In addition to practical skills, this course also encourages students to critically evaluate the complex relationships between the economy, aesthetic values and social behaviors within the global market-place. Special focus will be on emerging technologies and platforms concerning the global online art market.
outcome: Upon completing this course, students will be able to: • Identify the roles and activities of key players and institutions in the art market • Explain and analyze the history of the art market, patronage system and art market logic • Develop skills in art valuation, the buying and selling of art, creating agreements and understanding the laws that govern art transactions • Acquire personal and social competencies in connecting with the art community and pursuing future careers • Develop skills in critical analysis concerning the complex relationships between the economy, aesthetic values and social behaviors within the global marketplace • Develop an attitude of innovation and creativity by understudying emerging technologies and plat-forms concerning the global online art market

title: Music, Culture and Outreach
description: It is of crucial significance for cultural practitioners and managers to develop a solid foundation and capability in understanding the nature of music from various perspectives, as well as possessing the competency in appreciating the aesthetic and artistic value of musical works for the sake of advocating, marketing, coordinating and managing various programmes, events and outreach in music. Through exploring a wide range of music literature from different historical periods in music, the course focuses on three main perspectives:The first perspective focuses on listening and examining the major masterpieces in the history of music from Middle Ages to Modern, in which musical elements and characteristics of major forms and genres will be introduced and analysed. The second perspective is identified by the relationship of music to culture, in which the influence that cultural, social, political and religious events have exerted on music will be discussed. The third perspective focuses on experiencing and examining the approaches of music education in advocating music in the society. Through experiential learning, students will be able to develop basic knowledge and skills for applying the current theories and approaches in music education (e.g. play-based approach, Orff Schulwerk, Dalcroze, Kodaly) to outreach and education in the society.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: 1. Develop a comprehensive understanding of the musical elements which define styles, genres and historical periods of music; 2. Demonstrate cognitive, analytic and critical skills in analysing the musical works of different historical periods; 3. Gain comprehensive and in-depth understanding of the influence that cultural, social, political and religious events have exerted on music; 4. Understand pertinent education theories in music education and their implications on musical enculturation and advocacy; 5. Develop plans of introducing music through outreach activities to children and the general public by creative, play-based and other current music pedagogies such as Orff Schulwerk and Dalcroze.
syllabus: Part I: Basics in Music Appreciation  1. What is “Music Appreciation”?  This session gives an introduction to how to be an ‘educated’ listener’. Major elements and focus of listening in appreciating the aesthetic and artistic value of music will be introduced.  2. Roles of Music in the Society This session discusses the roles of music in the society and various impacts of music will be discussed. Also, this section investigates how cultural, social, political and religious events have influenced the development of music.  3. Understanding Orchestration  This session uses musical excerpts and examples to illustrate the characteristics and timbre/tone colour of a wide range of orchestral instruments, as well as various concepts on orchestration.   4. Field Trip Field trip to a music institution (e.g. orchestra) will be arranged for students to gain a deeper understanding on the various aspects of performance as well as management of music institutions.  Part II: A Journey to Appreciating Music  5. Music in Middle Ages (500-1400) and Renaissance (1450-1600) This session introduces the main characteristics of Middle Ages and Renaissance music. Major genres and musical styles of the Middle Ages will be discussed, e.g. Gregorian Chant, Mass, Estampe, Rondeau. Featured genres in the Renaissance will also be discussed, e.g. Motet, Mass, Madrigal, Lute Song, Polychoral Motet. Through exploring the musical works of Middle Ages and Renaissance, the interrelationship among music, culture and society will be discussed.  6. Music in the Baroque Period (1600-1750)  This session studies the main characteristics and musical style of Baroque music. Major forms and genres of Baroque music will be introduced and analysed, e.g. Opera, Solo Concerto, Prelude and Fugue, Cantata, Oratorio, Suite. Through exploring the musical works of Baroque period, the interrelationship among music, culture and society will be discussed.  7. Music in the Classical Period (1750-1820) This session studies the main characteristics and musical style of Classical Period. Major forms and genres of Baroque music will be introduced and analysed, e.g. sonata form, theme and variation, rondo, classical symphony, classical concerto.   8. Music in the Romantic Period (1820-1900)  This session studies the main characteristics of Romantic period. Romantic art songs, operas, programme music, and instrumental works will be introduced and analysed. Through exploring the musical works of Classical period, the interrelationship among music, culture and society will be discussed.  9. Modern Music (1900-Present)/Music of Non-Western Cultures This session studies the main characteristics of modern music. For example, expressionism, impressionism, 20th century nationalism, and Jazz music will be introduced and analysed. This session also examines the characteristics, musical styles, genres, instrumentation of music from non-western culture, e.g. music in sub-Saharan Africa, classical music of India, Koto music of Japan. Through exploring music of non-western cultures and the musical works of modern period , the interrelationship among music, culture and society will be discussed.  Part III: Bringing the Joy of Appreciating Music through Education  10. Current Theories and Practices in Music Education  This session focuses on discussing the current theories, thoughts, and approaches in music education, e.g. Developmentally Appropriate Practice (DAP), Play-Based Approach, Orff Schulwerk, and Dalcroze Approach. The application of these approaches and theories to music appreciation activities in outreach programmes will be discussed.  11. Workshop in Music Pedagogies (I) Through experiential learning and firsthand experience, this session introduces the skills and techniques in movement and choreography for conducting outreach and education in music. Musical excerpts discussed in Part II will be used as examples for illustration.  12. Workshop in Music Pedagogies (II) Through experiential learning and firsthand experience, this session introduces the skills and techniques in singing and chanting, and the application of percussion instruments for conducting outreach and education in music. Musical excerpts discussed in Part II will be used as examples for illustration.  13. Presentation and Conclusion

title: Visual Arts Management
description: This course leads students to study various modes and philosophies of visual arts management undertaken in different venues. Aesthetics and art criticisms are critical in directing art interpretation and presentation. Contemporary management of visual arts responds predominantly to the worldwide discussions on modernism as well as various post-modernist writings. In addition, it has to operate in accordance with the prescribed state policy. For this bilateral concern of art management, the course comprises two sections. The first section leads students to study the writings on aesthetics by critics from Plato to Foucault, whose arguments are still valid in inspiring many art exhibitions. The second section discusses the practical concerns and techniques in maximizing the social and economic impacts of art exhibitions and relevant events. Both sections discuss case studies taken from different parts of the world.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to describe different categories of visual arts in professional language; to define and explain the key terms in visual art literature; to appreciate and analyze art exhibitions with reference to intellectual debates on aesthetics; to describe and explain the art policies implemented in East Asia and the West; and to develop independent thinking on the operation and promotion of art organizations.
syllabus: Section I: Aesthetics and art criticisms   1. Introduction: Shifting perspectives on visual art management in the 20th century  Visual art management was a new discipline born in late 19th century when museums appeared in Europe. This session reviews the early practices in museum curatorship and its transformations under the impact of modernism. It explains how the focus in managing visual art shifted from scholarly field to public arena in the 21st century.   2. ‘Is it good art?’: From Plato, Hume to Danto on aesthetics  ‘What is beauty?’ has been the most discussed topic in Western art history since the times of Plato. This session discusses the canonical writings by Plato and his followers and critics during the times of Renaissance. The discussion links to their contributions to the post-modern theories that still weigh importantly today.   3. Visuality and Perception The intention of artists and the perception of arts of the beholders are core issues in Western aesthetics. This section discusses the most well-read writings by Ernest Gombrich and John Berger, who respond to the question as to whether arts comprise social values.   4. ‘Does Fine Arts still stand today?’: From fine arts to commercial arts  Visual arts comprise a wide range of categories today that include both traditional oil paintings and sculpture, as well as contemporary art forms that includes installation, and industrial designs. This section discusses the shifting definitions of arts and the incorporation of commercial arts in exhibitions.   5. Cross-cultural aesthetics  Are Western art theories applicable to the Asian contexts? Correlation exists between civilization and visual culture. This session discusses the Chinese visual art system and explains its difference from that in the West.   Section II: Concerns and Practices   6. Writing and arts  This lecture analyzes different texts about visual arts taken from museum exhibition catalogues, auction house catalogues, newspaper reviews, as well as commercial gallery publications. This leads students to reflect on the different presentations of arts for education and commercial purposes.   7. Arts and state  This lectures discusses the various policies implemented in the US, UK, and China that enables or hinders the developments of art organizations and individual artists.   8. Business and Arts  Artists and art organizations s management relies heavily on the patronage of business firm. This session discuss the mutual relationship between arts and business, as well as their shifting roles in recent decades.   9. Audience and arts  This lecture extends the discussion of the last, and focuses on the concerns and strategies of art and cultural promoters in non-profit, educational sectors. This introduces the issue of branding implemented in many world renowned institutes and evaluates their success.   10. Managers and arts  This lecture discusses human resources management in the art industry. Examples of excellent directorship taken from the UK and US will be studied to shed light on the significance of professional leadership in the discipline.   11. The Biennial fever  Bienne is world recognized art event to showcase and acknowledge the achievements of young artists. This lecture discusses the organization and social impacts of the bienne festivals held in Europe and Asia.   12. Artist villages  Artist village is developing everywhere in the world. This lectures discusses the examples found in China and Taiwan and leads students to think whether Hong Kong will need an artist cluster for future cultural developments.   13. Art events and festivals  Annual art events and festivals serve as major strategies to generate social and economic support for art today. This lecture discusses the organization and planning of those events and evaluate the examples taken from Europe, US and Asia.

title: Performing Arts Management
description: This course discusses the missions, administrations, and strategies of performing art organizations. Since the 1950s, performing art managers have realized the significance of efficient management in achieving popularity and sale. This course will go through the general topics as to how the performing art organizations are administered in national and legal terms; how they solicit funding; how they are operated in terms of ticketing and touring; and how they are strategically promoted for both branding and social benefits.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to describe the practical concerns of the performing art organizations in terms of their daily operation; to identify various sources of funding in support of performing arts; to evaluate the administration structure and strategies undertaken in different countries; and describe and explain the different policies implemented in East Asia and the West.
syllabus: 1. Introduction: Profit-making vs Non-profiting making performing houses  This lecture introduces the basic, binal division between two different types of performing houses. This leads students to reflect on the confliciting aims between the two types, and realize the significance of the overlapping features of the two.   2. Setting up the ‘mission’ Clear directorship is recognizedly important among performing arts management. This lecture analyzes the various mission statements and approach of the performing houses in Europe, US and China. This discusses how a mission statement is being written up and executed.   3. Legal rights and obligations of non-profit making organizations.  This lecture discusses the legal terms of the non-profiting making performing organizations, and provides an in-depth study towards their social obligations in exchange for tax exemption.   4. Commercial productions.  This lecture discusses the concerns and strategies of Broadway productions. Examples of programming and touring techniques of the theatres in the US, France and China will be discussed.   5. Budget planning  Financial management in the performing industry aims to maintain balance between expenses and revenue. This lecture discusses the management of book keeping, payroll taxes, facilities maintenance, and auditing.   6. Fund-raising possibilities for non-profit performing houses  There are many fund-raising opportunities for non-profit organizations. Managers usually have to work closely with the Board of Directors. Tactics in securing interests and long-term partnerships with external and potential donors will be discussed.  7. Sale and ticketing  Following up with the last session, this lecture discusses the marketing management of commercial productions. The role of ticket office and various advertising skills will be compared and discussed.   8. Performing arts and education  This lecture discusses the American tactics in engaging junior and high school students in performing arts. It discusses the experience of the New York City Centre and the Kennedy Centre. This session invites students to reflect on the social impacts of the performing industry through arts education.   9. Human resources  Theatres and Orchestras work closely with large numbers of members from various sorts of backgrounds. Management in labor relations has always been a key to achieve success in the performing industry. This section introduces various labour unions and legal regulations towards employment contracts.   10. Touring production  Touring is a common tactic employed to increase revenue by taking the performing crew overseas. However, touring means many risks that may increase expenses. This lecture discusses the benefits and shortcomings in taking a production on a tour.   11. Facility management  Facilities maintenance assumes a large share of expense on the financial sheet of presenters. This session discusses the contracting tactics in keeping the costs low. In addition, it also discusses event programming that draws attention to the management of facilities.   12. Internship and youth programmes  This lecture discusses the outreach options for performing houses. It will focus on the networking and partnership formed on the basis of short-term internship; and on the audience-engaging programme that develops the audience base of different age range.   13. Presentation  Student presentation of group project.

title: Film and Literature: Inter-Media Studies
description: This course's objective is to acquaint students with the kindred relationships between film and literature as well as to help them develop a more critical awareness to appreciate these two media from a cultural studies perspective. It will cover the following topics: introduction to the art of film, the generic and mediumistic comparisons of film and literature: film and the novel or film and drama or the theatre, etc.

title: Animals, Culture and Modern Society
description: (UGEC3481 is double-coded with CURE3003.)  How do we understand and connect to animal kingdom?How do human-animal connections shape modern culture and society?How do cultural studies and humanities expand our scope on animal and nature?Culture is ordinary, in Raymond William’s saying, but the ordinariness is merely treated as a reflection of human everyday life. Although cultural studies has sustained concern on everyday life with mass production, consumerism, sexism, racism and postmodernism, the discipline always lags behind the concern of nature and animal species. As the issues of animal abuse, environmental protection, factory farming, animal protection policy and law-making, as well as media various portrayals being the hot topics of our (post)modern world, the study of animal with the perspective of cultural studies and other humanity disciplines can explore the possibilities of better human-animal relationship. This course is designed with an empathic concern of other-than-human animals. By exploring different issues of human and animals’ life, this course looks for a harmonious balance of nature and modern culture.This course focuses on three areas, through which we can explore the different aspects of animal and cultural studies. These areas are:A. Entering Jurassic Park – Remaking Animals in Leisure (Lecture A1-A4)B. Attacking Godzilla – Representing Animals in Media (Lecture B1-B4)C. Finding Nemo – Revitalizing Animals in the City  (Lecture C1-C4)Each area covers a set of animal issue discussion. Area A, apart from theorizing animal with cultural studies, tackles the basic animal issues: pet-nurturing, zoo-building, forest-sustaining and tourism. This is to provide a foundation for understanding animals with a critical reflection of everyday life. Area B, set with the concern of media, discusses issues of animal representation in cartoon, cinema, literature and journalism. This is to read how animals would be represented and how this affects human understanding and related policy-making. A screening will be run after Lecture Area B. This is to provide an alternative understanding of animal representation in popular media. Area C further deals with the matters of animal-city relationship in seeing how dogs and cats, cattle and swine, and fishes and dolphins are (mal)treated in the street, the farm and the sea respectively. This is to end the course with a leading thought of perfect balance of nature and modernity; and more queries of human-animal relationship will be raised for contemplation.
outcome: Learning Outcomes: On successful completion of the course, students are expected to be able to:  Explain the concern of other-than-human animal with cultural studies perspective;  Identify the key issues and critical assessment of human-animal relationship;  Understand the approach in studying culture, animal and environment;  Enrich the angle of analyzing human living and animal species.
