title: Museum Studies
requirements: Not for students who have taken CUMT3108 or ANTH4720 or HIST5514
description: Museums have multiple roles in a society. They are academic institutes and public arenas for education. In the broad term, they represent national culture and communal heritage. This course leads students to understand museum exhibitions and management within social contexts. The lectures respond to the following issues:1. What are the functions and achievements of museum activities?2. In what ways can we understand and learn from an exhibition? What are the essential elements of museum catalogues and cultural writing?3. How do museum workers balance both marketing and social needs?4. In what ways can we participate in the operation of a museum?The course draws discussions from both the perspectives of museum workers and visitors. Some current issues concerning the roles of museums are also covered.
outcome: At the end of the course, students should be able to:  1. Identify the roles and management of museums;  2. Develop acute senses for art appreciation;  3. Develop interests in culture and history; and  4. Think critically about museum exhibitions and other cultural events.
syllabus: 1 Introduction:What is a museum?  The introduction gives an overview of the museum structure and definition. This will introduce the various types of museums established around the world, defined according to the range of their collections. This will also compare the organization structure of a museum, in which the curatorial teams are working with a range of specialists relevant.   2 The history of museums  The ‘history’ of museum sounds alien to the context of museum studies. But museum workers are coming to beware that the museums are products of modernity that marked a distinctive times in which antiquities could be treated as shared, public properties. This lecture reviews the establishments of the Louvre and the British Museum in the 18th century; and discusses how ‘museums’ were contextualized first in Japan and later on in China.   3 Curatorship I: Exhibiting Authenticity and Interpretation As the last lecture recalls, ‘Museum as Ritual’ has become an established social understanding—museum is a place where esteemed objects are being exhibited and therefore recognized. The first problem that encounters all museum works is whether the objects they are showing, or the theme of the objects that they are presenting are ‘authentic’. In this lecture, we will look at examples of some early colonial museums and study the created themes that they presented.   4 Curatorship II: Organizing a thematic exhibition Putting up a thematic exhibition (alongside the permanent exhibition) is a common practice in most museums. This lecture will give instructions as to what elements a thematic show should include. Then students are organized into groups to do a role play session for three parties: museum workers, overseas collaborators, and the donors. From this exercise, students will learn about the difficulties in negotiations and planning.   5 Curatorship III: Museum publications and cultural writings The writings published for the museums share a common theme of identifying the artistic or historical values of the objects. In practice, however, there are various levels in addressing objects through literary practices. This lecture will look into some representative examples written for different targeted groups, which include children, pupils, and foreign visitors.   6 Museum and society I: Architecture and Design Renovation projects were undertaken in numerous renowned museums around the world, because it has become aware that museums have to catch up with young generations and with the rapidly developed cities, in which they are located. This lecture will look into the case of Doha Quarter, where the locals took a deliberate attempt to a museum compound. From such we will consider the significance of architecture and museum collection.   7 Museum and society II: Education and Application of Digital Technology  Smartphones and other technological devices have become useful sources for museum presentations and visits. This lecture reviews some applications both within the museum building and outside it. The lecture will also respond to the concerns that digital technologies may exhaust public interests in the museum collections. With these both sides of argument, this lecture leads students to consider both the usefulness and shortcomings of digital technologies.   8 Museum and society III: Patrons, Donors and Volunteers, the sources of Funding and Support Funding is always limited for cultural institutions. In this lecture, we will discuss the various potential fund sources for the museums. There is no standard way in the industry as to what the museum workers should do or write to apply for funding. But there are recognized sources about which they could get in touch: public visitors, membership programmes, volunteers, donars, and governmental resources. The key of the lecture is to develop an open mind to expand the coverage of funding from monetary values to public recognition.   9 Current issue I: Museum Branding and Marketing Museum branding has been identified as a major marketing strategy for cultural institution. In this lecture, we will look at the suggestions of some successful museum workers and study their marketing approaches by creating a brand for museums.   10 Current issue II: Soft Power and the Political Roles of Museums. As soon as Joseph Nye published his idea about soft power, which is based on the dissemination of cultural products or ideas, the discussion is always concerned with museum exhibitions. Museums could be taken as political statement of national treasures. In this lecture, we will discuss the ideas of Nye and look at how such concept has been interpreted in Asia.   11 Fieldtrip/site visit week  This week we will take some fresh air by visiting a local museum/site.   12 Current issue III: Museums and Contemporary Arts.  Should we include contemporary art in the context of museum? This is a difficult question that happens to most museums around the world. The well-used resolution is construction of a new venue dedicated to contemporary arts. The differences between the two disciplines—museums and contemporary arts—are related to the level of curatorship and public recognition. But the two themes seem to have blurred since the last decade.   13 Current issue IV: M+ and other museums in Hong Kong In this last session, we will return our discussion to Hong Kong and look at what options this city has in comparison from what we have seen in other parts of the world. The M+ is dedicated to contemporary arts, or experimental arts; but the local museums remain fairly traditional in terms of collection and their range of exhibitions. Can Hong Kong develop a cultural hub? If so, what roles do these institutes would play?

title: Global Cultural Theories
description: Departing from the dominant canon of critical theory, this course aims to introduce students to a wider, more diverse range of theoretical texts and frameworks by marginalized voices and from peripheral locations.This course seeks to decolonize theory by multiplying the sites of intellectual and critical inquiry. Instead of treating Benjamin, Adorno, Hall, and Grossberg as representative of the corpus of theory, it engages with prevailing discussions in Postcolonial Studies, Modernity/Coloniality, and Black Studies. It moves beyond the call for ‘de-Westernization’ by looking at theoretical texts and frameworks produced in Asia, Africa, and Latin America. The course concludes by exploring work about indigeneity, memory, and environmentalism. The course is designed for advanced undergraduates with familiarity in critical approaches to literature, cinema, art, and media. Classes will grapple with the following questions: What qualifies as theory? Is theory necessarily abstract? What is the relationship of theory to particularity and difference? How can theory be made more attune to its contexts of production, dissemination, and application? How can film and visual art offer sources for theorizing? How might theoretical frameworks respond more significantly to social, economic, and environmental conditions from the restructuring of the capitalist system, expansion of media networks, dissolution of national borders, and deterioration of the climate crisis?
outcome: The objectives are:   To become acquainted with theoretical texts and frameworks in Cultural Studies by marginalized voices from different peripheral social and geographic contexts To apply theory to analyze the articulation of race, gender, memory, and nature in literature, cinema, art, and media To formulate, develop, write, and revise an original critical essay using global cultural theories

title: Graduation Thesis
description: This course provides an opportunity for students to undertake supervised study on a selected topic of interest. Students will be led to examine aspects of the selected topic, conduct a critical literature review and a systematic investigation of the topic they have chosen. Students are required to regularly discuss with the teacher concrete findings in their research and submit written progress reports as scheduled by the teacher and a complete project report at the end of the term.
outcome: 1.Apply theory critically to analyse cultural texts they interested. 2.Use a self-reflective approach to devising and developing an academic paper. 3.Reflectively evaluate their learning and personal planning processes.

title: Time, Space, and Identity in World Cinema
description: This course aims to introduce you to a range of films from world cinema that illuminate the ways in which cinema as an art-form and a cultural product has engaged with issues of space, time and identity and reformulated our very experience of these arenas. It uses a range of critical frameworks to enable you to understand how the study of film can reconfigure understandings of space and its cultural production; temporality, speed and the practice of everyday life; and the representation of bodies as having a particular gender, race and sexuality.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:  At the end of the course, you will: • Have an understanding and an appreciation of a wide range of films from around the world • Have been introduced to and engaged with contemporary debates and issues in film studies and critical theory • Have enhanced visual analysis and close reading skills from film analysis work

title: Critical Approaches to Pornography
components:
Field Studies/Field-trip
Laboratory
Lecture
Interactive Tutorial
description: The course will offer an introduction to critical views on pornography, which is defined as sexually explicit media within different cinematic traditions and digital screen cultures. The aim of the course is to show that pornography is a not a unified screen culture but consists of varied representations within cultural contexts. The course will teach students how to analyze these representations and how to take into account their cultural histories. The course will take a Cultural Studies approach and examine within specific cultural environments and include the positions of anti-porn and pro-porn activists. Therefore students will get an overview of diverging perspectives while being encouraged to consider their own values and critical responses. Students will be asked to respond to theories and audio-visual examples, while actively partaking in debates about pornography and its impact on religion, gender, sexuality, health, labor and economy. Finally, the course will pay special importance to how contemporary sexually explicit media are impacting new user groups such young adult netizens, female consumers, disabled people, as well as ethnic and sexual minorities. Students will carry out a major assignment while learning how to apply ethnographic research methods to analyze representations of the body and sexuality within screen cultures. In this assignment, they will focus on a media environment/platform and a sexual culture of their choice to find out how culture is being redefined and visualized by media users. Two workshops will be organized in the media lab in order to train the students in different methods and perspectives on digital ethnographyLanguage of instruction: Classes and assignments will be carried out in the English language and students’ active participation in both lectures and tutorials will be required. Students can carry out ethnographic fieldwork in Cantonese or any language of your choice, but need to present the results in English.Learning Activities: Students are required to attend a 3-hour class each week. The course combines theoretical lectures with the viewing of films and media examples. There will also be tutorial sessions each week based on the lectures and on the weekly readings. All students are required to post weekly reflections on Blackboard and to participate in discussions. In addition to the weekly readings and reflections, students will conduct research and planning for their assessments and oral presentations independently and in groups.Please be advised that this course will involve some screenings and discussions of sexually explicit materials and category III films. Therefore, students under 18 years-old are advised not to take this course.

title: Film Classics: Aesthetics and Politics
description: This course aims at introducing some of the major film classics from America (Hollywood), Europe (France and Italy), Japan, and China produced from the earliest era to circa 1960. They will be viewed and studied in a cultural and historical context, together with detailed analysis of their form and content in order to understand their "canonical" status. Basic film theories - especially those dealing with film genres and film "auteurs" - will also be used.

title: Workshop in Creative Content
description: Through workshops, this course aims to cultivate students' creative thinking and abilities of artistic expression. It leads students to explore various art forms, such as graphics, sound, non-fiction narrative, drama, experimental film, and cross/inter-disciplinary arts, etc. Specific projects are planned and executed around particular themes through primarily teacher-student consultations and discussions supplemented by lectures. It helps students grasp creative skills to express their opinions and emotions effectively using audiovisual elements. This advanced practical course requires students to have completed the foundational course CURE2066 Visual Design Foundation in advance.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: Develop the creative and technical skills necessary to express students' opinions. Enhance the ability to appreciate and think critically about various forms of artistic works while developing the critical, analytical, and editing skills necessary to evaluate works in progress, both in the student's own projects and those of their peers. Improve students' communication and teamwork skills. Learn how to showcase works and develop the ability to engage in dialogues with society.

title: Arts, Propaganda and Social Action
description: The course studies the history, theories and techniques of organizing cultural activities for social and political causes. It investigates the relationship between cultural expressions and the infrastructure of power, and the application of arts and culture for social, political actions, covering such major movements from the avant-garde of the 19th Century, the USSR and the Chinese propaganda movements, to the arts for civil right movements since 1960s. Case studies of similar movements in Hong Kong will also be included. The final part of the course will introduce to students the operational and managerial skill required for organizing such cultural activities.

title: Digital Imaging, Book Production and Contemporary Arts
description: This course will teach the conceptual foundations and implement the use of practices of digital imaging and book production okmaking within contemporary arts. The course will also teach aspects of contemporary art and photography as a documentary and conceptual medium. It will focus on digital imaging’s ability to enhance existing literature, and reproduce or manipulate pre-existing images. Students will be expected to equally apply digital imaging applications in a technically adept and creative manner with an eye towards given art historical movements and examples such as Dada and Surrealism.The course will be based on software instruction, as well as use of digital scanning, digital photography and video productions . Assignments will include (but not be limited to) desktop publishing for the making of artist books, catalogues “zines” (inexpensive DIY magazines) and e-books that are consumed on various digital media format such websites, mobile phones and i-pad tablets.

title: Documentary Studies: Theories and Practices
description: The course explores the history and basic theory of documentary film. General concepts, aesthetics, ethics and different forms of documentary will be introduced as well. The aim of it is to help students develop a critical understanding and appreciation of documentary through lecture, screening, practical workshop and experience of creating a film. It also helps them to know how to discover and represent the cultural phenomenon in daily life by using visual method. Students are expected to finish their short documentary films at the end of the semester.
outcome: To equip students with general knowledge of the concepts and the history of documentary film.  • To analyze the close connection between history, culture, and cinema in documentary film.   • Students will understand how to conceive, shoot and edit a documentary.  • To use digital media as a tool in research and as a method of presenting research outcomes.

title: Summer Internship
description: Process of cultural production and cultural practices at various levels are essential to the training of cultural sensitivity and analysis in cultural studies. This course aims to provide students with on-site experience of cultural production and practices for their reflection and integration of cultural theories and concepts they learnt in regular classes. Students will be introduced to a range of cultural institutions and culture-related non-governmental organizations for a placement of eight weeks between May to July during summer. Students will be asked to attend several sessions of orientations and evaluation before and during their placement.
outcome: Objectives:  Provide learning and practicing opportunities for students
syllabus: 1) First meeting with all year 2 students 2) Final submission date for the internship application 3) Matching students with partner institutions 4) Group interview with applicants 5) Finalize the results of internship allocation 6) Internship starts 7) Meeting & sharing session I 8) Meeting & sharing session II 9) Submission of written report by students 10) Submission of evaluation report by institutions

title: AI, Arts and Technology
description: What is the big deal about computational technologies for the arts? This course explores the evolution, current state, and future implications of artificial intelligence (AI) in art and media. This course provides an overview of the history of AI and computation from Norbert Wiener’s Cybernetics to OpenAI’s ChatGPT. Besides concepts, students will explore the theories of art and technology through field trips and practices. Although history and critique are central to this course, students will also gain some hands-on experience in applications of AI in art. This course includes lectures, projects, and critical discussions. At the end of the course, students will be able to critically evaluate the inevitable integration of AI in creative workflows and its implications for the future of art, and articulate the critical issues and ethical implications of AI on creative arts.

title: Chan School of Buddhism
description: The Chan movement has been described by Hu Shih as a reformation or revolution in Buddhism and by Suzuki as a movement in which the Chinese mind completely asserted itself, in a sense, in opposition to the Indian mind. This course examines the Chan movement from a historical perspective. Attention will also be paid to the study of basic scriptures of the Chan School of Buddhism.

title: Selected Taoist Classics
description: This course consists of reading of the classical literature of Taoism formulated in its early phase of development. Students are trained to understand Taoism through original textual reading. Selections include the T'ai-ping ching, the Pao-p'u tzu, the Chen-kao, and the Laotzu Hsiang-erh chu.
outcome: To be able to understand religion in its historical settings and contemporary contexts of modern living; globally and locally and to analyze how contemporary religious expressions shape and are shaped by global and local cultural, social, and political trends.

title: Integrated Studies in Cultural Management
description: This course is continuation of CUMT1001, Introduction to Cultural Management, and looks at cultural management from the macro perspective. Successful culture managers work to maintain healthy balance between culture and its relevant fields of interests, which sometimes could turn harmful or beneficial to the growth and development of the corresponding cultural area. The first session discusses the mutual dependence between culture and various areas, which include laws, economy, community, national interests, and art practitioners. In practice, cultural managers usually have to conform to the values and ethnics of the corresponding countries. For that reason, the second session will look at the approach taken in a few remarkable examples, which Taiwan, China, Singapore, South Korea, U.K., and the U.S.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to explain different national and social concerns for preserving culture; to identify the legal and ethnic issues relevant to cultural productions; to identify marketing strategies in cultural promotion; to evaluate the measures for maximizing the input of art practitioners; and to describe the various successful cultural schemes implemented in overseas countries.
syllabus: Section I: Culture in Context   1. Culture & States The growth of cultural industries is strongly related to political environment and state policy. This lecture discusses the tension and mutual expectations between cultural workers and politicians. It will use the experience of the European Union and the US as examples.   2. Culture & Laws Over the last few decades, there were a number of remarkable disputes over international art transactions and copy rights. Given the growing size of the art market, knowledge about the previous cases is essential. This lecture takes the examples taken from the US for discussions.   3. Culture & UNESCO UNESCO is arguably a rising new power in forming a standard for evaluating cultural heritage of different nations. This lecture discusses the roles of UNESCO and its work in different cultural disciplines. National disputes over ownership of World Heritage sites will be bought up.   4. Culture & Community Nowadays many nations and countries perceive culture and heritage as means to empower developing communities. This lecture discusses the conservation of indigenous or minorities cultures, and its impacts on the majority population of the same community.   5. Culture & Marketing  Culture and business are often taken as two contrasting disciplines. One of the key issues in cultural management is to develop cultural audience with both education and economic concerns. Religious sectors are a growing body of cultural venues for tourism and heritage management. This lecture discusses the debated concerns about conducting marketing or business-driven strategies in cultural and religious areas.   Section II: Case Studies 6. Cultural Management in Taiwan Taiwan provides an excellent example to demonstrate the top-down organization of heritage sites. This lecture reviews a series of campaigns launched in Taiwan during the past twenty years, and discusses the reasons that may have contributed to engage the mass of Taiwan into different aspects of cultural industries.   7. Cultural Management in China China represents many upcoming opportunities in cultural management. This lecture reviews some recent moves: rapid establishment of museums, growing number of commercial galleries and auction houses, rise of new Confucian schools, introduction of university degrees in cultural management, etc. The lecture discusses the consuming force underneath the cultural growth in the Mainland.   8. Cultural Management in Singapore During the last two decades, the government of Singapore invested heavily on constructing cultural venues for both national and economic purposes. This lecture gives an overview of their establishment and invites students to reflect on the opportunities found in other areas of Asia.   9. Cultural Management in South Korea This lecture discusses the contemporary cultural policies undertaken in South Korea. During the last decade, South Korea featured an economic miracle in Asia by rejuvenating the distressed financial market with cultural developments, which included the film industry, heritage protection, publication, and cultural tourism.   10. Cultural Management in UK The United Kingdom was one of the earliest countries that invested heavily on promotion of cultural and arts events. This lecture gives a short history of the early developments made in the UK after the Second World War, and discusses the recent campaigns undertaken to break the boundaries between high arts and popular culture.   11. Cultural Management in USA The United States distinguishes herself from all other countries by boosting the absence of a ministry for arts and culture, yet artists and cultural workers receive due respects for their contributions. This lecture looks at the case of the US and examines her success in cultural management.   12. Group presentation This lecture is taken as a mock symposium for students to present their group projects and make comments on those by their peers. The presentation will be evaluated against the clarity and thoughts over the approved topics.   13. Conclusion: What is the best for Hong Kong?  This last session will summarize the topics covered throughout the course. Hong Kong is facing the challenge that many aspects of cultural developments in relation to urban planning, legislation, economy, national identity, and education are all pending. This lecture is an open discussion for students to brainstorm the possible approaches that Hong Kong could take in years to come.

title: Culture-led City Development
description: This course aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the culture-led city development phenomenon and equip them with the protocols for execution and practice. It comprises three blocks: Block 1 unfolds an overall picture of the phenomenon, introduces the related concepts, displays the disciplinary foundation of this topic, traces its history, and discusses the rationales and developing tendency. Block 2 studies the urban sociological and economic approaches employed in developing the theoretical foundation, highlighting a transition in capitalist production mode and urban governance upheld by public-private partnership modes. Criticisms are also presented to complete a dialectic mindset of this phenomenon. With a strong practical dimension, Block 3 teaches students various methods to make consultancy and policy recommendations for culture-led urban development projects. A variety of practices that constitute the culture-led strategy are discussed, such as how to plan for a creative city and cultural facilities, how to boost creative industries and develop cultural quarters and creative clusters, as well as how to revitalize historic quarters.
outcome: Students are introduced to the basic concept of the culture-led urban development phenomenon, recognizing related concepts, understanding its history, and developing tendencies in the world. Then, they can gain a deep theoretical understanding of the origins of these practices in a capitalist political economic transition, the corresponding urban policies, and the urban governance modes. Moreover, students can learn how to conduct policy analysis and apply urban planning and design principles to provide consultancy for culture-led city development projects. The final products of group projects shall consist of policy recommendations and project consultancies for the Hong Kong government or other private sector developers.
syllabus: Part 1: Introduction to the Culture-led City Development Phenomenon 1. Culture-led City Development: A Topic of Popularity With a glimpse into a number of cities in Europe, America, and Asia that have implemented culture-led urban regeneration strategies, this lecture aims to spark the students’ initial interest in this global phenomenon. This lecture identifies the disciplinary foundations of the topic—from cultural studies, economic geography, and urban sociology to urban planning and design. Furthermore, this lecture examines the concept of culture in the culture-led city development phenomenon, emphasizing the increasing importance of culture in the related disciplines in the mindset of “culture determining.” The role of culture in generating profits, jobs, and other economic returns, being interwoven with local governance and identity is discussed.   2. Concepts, History, Rationale, and Debate This section introduces a set of concepts closely related to that of “culture-led city development,” such as “cities of culture,” “property-led development” and “culture-led regeneration,” and differentiates the nuances among these concepts. The theories that argue for the role of culture in city formation and urban development are discussed, in which culture is viewed as resource or capital leading to symbolic economy that valorizes cities. A related issue is the role of cultural planning, which offers the resources and the framework in the process. The other theoretical source under scrutiny in this section is the importance of city or an urban environment to the growth of culture and cultural consumption. The writings of Jane Jacobs, Sharon Zukin, and Grame Evans are introduced.  Tutorial: Discuss selected readings.    Part 2: Urban Sociological and Economic Approach to Understanding Culture-led Urban Regeneration 3. Politics, Cultural Policies, and Culture-led City Development Strategies  This section explores the theoretical foundation of the culture-led city development phenomenon within the context of political economy. The transition of the capitalist production mode from Fordist economy to market-led post-Fordist economy has led to corresponding transitions in urban policies and urban governance modes, as well as to the adoption of public-private partnership. Culture-led city development strategy is a strategy, which is in line with the entrepreneurial urban policies. In addition, this section examines the connection between the culture-led city development strategies and the transformed cultural policies in cities. The broadening of the policy focus from art amenity provision to cultural economy development and urban cultural spaces planning has been identified as the most important policy context. Three stages of culture-led urban regeneration in terms of policies are also explained in detail.  Tutorial: Discuss selected readings.  4. Economy of Culture and Arts in Cities  This section discusses the economic importance of culture and arts in cities. Culture is viewed as a new driver in urban economic growth, and the cultural sector is viewed as an indicator of urban economic growth. The economic importance of culture is associated with the so-called “symbolic economy” in cities, which involves upgrading urban images and boosting cultural consumption (e.g., urban tourism) within specific urban economies. Cultural and creative industries are the other main focal points of this lecture; thus, the geographic dimensions of cultural and creative industries are explored in this section. Furthermore, this lecture elaborates on the characteristics of cultural industry businesses and organizations, the geographic distribution of networks, and their production and consumption modes. Finally, a method to measure cultural and creative industries in cities is introduced.  Tutorial: Discuss selected readings.   5. Culture-led Urban Regeneration Regimes and Cultural Strategies Bianchini divides cultural culture-led city development strategies into culture-production-led and culture-consumption-led regeneration approaches. This section explores four types of production-led regeneration regimes and the consumption-led regime mode; cultural strategies and their interactions with modes of cultural production are also discussed. In addition, this section addresses the question of whether cultural strategies affect the conditions of cultural production. Finally, a method to fund cultural strategies is studied. Tutorial: Discuss selected readings.   6. Urban Governance and Partnership Modes in Culture-led City Development  What are the urban governance modes that match individual culture-led city development practices? The transformation of urban governance and partnership modes, which is a response to the change in the capitalist production mode, is an important issue in understanding of culture-led urban development practices. Partnership is not simply a transition from managerial to entrepreneurial form but a public sector-led management to local public-private partnership to manage their opportunities effectively in the global economic background. This section explores the characteristics of urban governance and public-private partnership. This knowledge can be applied in creating cultural quarters, CCJQs, and cultural facilities in Block 3.  Tutorial: Discuss selected readings.  7. Critiques on Culture-led Urban Regeneration Culture-led urban development strategies result in positive urban outcomes; however, they can also have negative impacts. This section presents the criticisms against culture-led urban development. For example, designation and zoning of cultural quarters often lead to the gentrification effect that cuts off poor artists from industrial studios. Flagship cultural facilities have a high chance of failure, often resulting in social exclusion and economic inequality and trigger tensions between cultural diversity and cultural hegemony. Moreover, the contribution of cultural projects to employment and GDP is questioned. Tutorial: Discuss selected readings.    Part 3: Strategies and Mechanisms for Practice: Policies, Urban Planning, and Design Tools 8. Cultural Planning and Creative Cities  This section introduces the concept of “cultural planning” as well as its goals, principles, and rationale for practice. The major steps for practice are discussed briefly. The second issue in this lecture is related to creative city and creative milieu. Based on the concept of “creative city” introduced in CUMT1001, this lecture discusses the principles and methods to create a creative milieu for a city. Further discussions are based on the insights of Landry regarding the components of creative cities and Hall about the characteristics and preconditions for the creation of creative cities.  Mid-term Test  9. Boosting Cultural and Creative Industries in Cities  This section discusses a method of using policy and planning tools to boost cultural and creative industries in cosmopolitan cities. First, the three stages of cultural industry development in connection with cultural policy transformations in history are reviewed. Second, a method is introduced, by which policies for cultural and creative industry development can be designed and initiated. Sophisticated analyses of local resources of arts, cultural industries and their interconnections, along with production chain linkage and planning assessment, comprise the key steps in creating effective policy designs. The geographic convergence of cultural businesses and creative industry undertakings in the form of clustering has been argued to be a possible mechanism to facilitate the growth of cultural and creative industries. Finally, the principles and methods to generate CCJQs using policy and planning methods are outlined in this section. Tutorial: Draft a proposal aimed at transforming Hong Kong into a creative city.  10. Planning for Public Arts, Arts Amenities, and Cultural Facilities Developing cultural facilities through urban planning and design is an integral part of culture-led urban development. This section examines the position of arts amenities in urban policies through various historical stages, as well as the transition from emphasizing arts amenity provision to cultural facilities in urban planning. The main content of this lecture is devoted to providing instruction with regard to the ways by which to plan for cultural facilities in cosmopolitan cities, with an outline of the main approaches, such as providing cultural facilities as per the related planning codes with complementary methods of survey, designing a hierarchical system of cultural facility provision, developing facilities of mixed-use, and engaging member of the community. The anti-planning approach to creating cultural spaces is also included, the core concern of which involves a flexibly use of public and community spaces and family-centered virtual media facilities.  Tutorial: Analyze the policies of Hong Kong’s cultural and creative industries, and draft policy recommendations for creative industry development in Hong Kong.  11. Creating Cultural Quarters  Cultural quarters, rooted in post-Fordist economy, have become an integral part of urban regeneration regime, which represents a transition in urban cultural policies toward a more comprehensive stage. This section discusses the political and economic importance of cultural quarters, the rationale of clustering cultural activities and creative industry businesses, and the typology of cultural quarters. Students are also introduced to the strategies and principles for creating cultural quarters based on Roodhouse’s writings in 2006. Urban design skills to enhance the robustness of buildings and create vibrant street spaces and pedestrian spaces are complemented to Roodhouse’s principles. Possible solutions to control gentrification are also discussed using the case of Lace Market. The final part of this section presents the instructor’s consultancy project for the West Kowloon Cultural District. Tutorial: Come up with recommendations for improving cultural facilities in Hong Kong.  12. Heritage Conservation and Historic Urban Quarter Revitalization The significance of historical buildings and urban heritage sites in making a creative urban creative milieu and the process of disseminating symbols through cultural consumption-led urban spaces have been covered by previous sections. In this section, students are introduced to the historical transition and developing tendency of historic buildings and heritage conservation from preserving individual buildings to area-based conservation. With a clarification of the meaning of historic quarters, this section focuses on the selection of appropriate approaches or strategies that can be used in revitalizing historic urban quarters. These methods include preservation and conservation controls as well as physical and economic revitalization based on the assessment of the type of obsoletion.  Tutorial: Consultancy report for a cultural district in Hong Kong  13. The Workshop: Making Culturally Reenergized Cities In this section, the final group is expected to present their group project on historical quarter revitalization in Hong Kong. To wrap up this course, the final section summarizes all the key issues and points. Supplemental instructions are provided based on the progress of the students’ group projects, after which all comments on each group’s projects are synthesized. One or two mechanisms might be introduced to strengthen the students’ capacity to apply the theories learned, such as the evaluation matrix for cultural quarters and historic building reuses. A Q&A section is then included to answer students’ questions concerning the knowledge in this course. Moreover, additional supervision for individual group projects is provided as needed.

title: Heritage and Modern Applications
requirements:
1. Pre-requisites: CUMT3009 Interpreting Chinese Antiquities or CURE3409 Interpretation of Heritage or its equivalence
2. Not for students who have taken CUMT4004.
description: Cultural heritage is not confined to the past but is continuously carried forward into the present and future through various modern applications. These applications address current societal concerns, needs, and the ever-changing culture both locally and globally. The relevance of cultural heritage is influenced by complex power structures, including its presentation and representation in contexts such as postcolonialism, racial dynamics, gender, intergenerational equity, disparities in access to technology, marginalization, and the tension between localism and globalization. Additionally, the modern application of cultural heritage is shaped by evolving economic structures and technological advancements. Heritage is increasingly utilized by creative industries, with its assets digitized, interpreted, and experienced through advanced technologies such as AI and VR. Ensuring the continued relevance of cultural heritage has become a critical issue.This course aims to provide students with an understanding of cultural heritage and its diverse modern applications, along with the critical concepts that shape our perception of its relevance today. It addresses issues concerning cultural heritage and its relationship with changing urban demographics, climate change, intergenerational equity, and the application of technologies for future alternatives. Additionally, the course explores cultural heritage as an economic generator, its role in performance, sports, and games, and its adoption in personalized tours and emerging cultural industries. Through a variety of concepts and case studies, students will gain multiple perspectives on current practices and reflect on the vast potential of cultural heritage in contemporary times.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students would be able to:   Explore key examples of cultural heritage and its diverse modern applications, along with the critical concepts that shape our perception of its relevance today. Understand the modern applications of cultural heritage. Explain cases where cultural heritage acts as an economic generator. Reflect on broader critical issues surrounding the modern applications of cultural heritage, including but not limited to postcolonialism, racial dynamics, and other related topics. Cultivate an attitude of innovation and creativity by challenging assumptions within existing applications and projecting future directions in cultural heritage.
syllabus: 1. Introduction to Cultural Heritage in the 21st Century Contemporary needs and concerns Relevance of cultural heritage today Importance and impact in contemporary society 2. Cultural Heritage and Changing Demographics Effects of migration and multiculturalism Social class and diasporic cultures 3. Heritage and Climate Change Impact of climate change on cultural heritage Strategies for adaptation in cultural heritage plans 4. Intergenerational Equity and Alternative Futures Preserving heritage for future generations Sustainable practices in heritage management 5. Heritage as an Economic Generator Economic benefits of cultural heritage Heritage tourism and local economies 6. Heritage as Performance Performing arts as cultural heritage Preservation and promotion through performances 7. Heritage and Sport Sports and games as heritage 8. Personalized Cultural Heritage Tours Customizing heritage experiences 9. Virtual Heritage Environments (1) Virtual museum experiences Tools and technologies used in virtual environments Enhancing visitor engagement 10. Virtual Heritage Environments (2) Digitization of heritage assets Applications of AR in heritage interpretation Use of AI, VR, and other technologies in heritage 11. Future Directions in Cultural Heritage Emerging trends and future challenges Innovations shaping the future of heritage

title: Advanced Museum Studies
requirements:
1. Pre-requisite(s): CUMT3108 Museum Studies or CURE3508 Museum Studies
2. Not for students who have taken CUMT4008.
description: This course picks up topics, which cannot be fully covered in CUMT4007 Museum Studies, but are essential for students pursuing careers in the area of museum and exhibition planning. This course is an advanced version, because it will touch on debated issues regarding museums. It focuses on installation, display, and site management. The purposes of the course may be summarized as follows: 1. What are the various display methods in museums? What are the concerns involved in selecting the ‘right’ ones? 2. How are museum workers (non-curatorial) trained? 3. What are the essential facilities a museum is expected to have? Why? 4. What is the role of museum in the contemporary arts, which is the area of debate regarding its significance and curatorship? The course develops students’ awareness towards global developments in world-class museums, so that they are equipped with skills and knowledge necessary for long-term competition in museums or other cultural institutions.
outcome: At the end of the course, students should be able to:  1. Analyze exhibition display methods and theories.  2. Think critically about display and social concerns.  3. Clarify the roles and potentials of museum workers.  4. Get prepared for career related to management of museums and cultural industries.
syllabus: 1. Introduction: the Unseen Impacts of Museums  Museums make impacts in our societies in many ways, but they are usually gone unnoticed, almost unseen. What are the popular ways taken to measure the impacts of museums? And how useful (and meaningful) are they?  Readings: a. Paulus, Odile. "Measuring Museum Performance: A Study of Museums in France and the United States." International Journal of Arts Management 6, no. 1 (October 1, 2003): 50-63. b. Jacobsen, John W. Measuring museum impact and performance theory and practice (Chapters 2&3). Lanham: Rowman & Littlefield, 2016. PART I Display and Installation 2. Oral Histories I Not everything in the museum is tangible. In many cases, the objects are reminders of something unheard, unseen, or even almost forgotten. Oral histories are a common way to preserve the dying records. This lecture introduces the practice of building oral history records, and get students to develop their set of questions to preserve extinguishing cultural practices or knowledge.  Reading: a. Barnes, Lindsey; Guise, Kim. "World War Words: The Creation of a World War II–Specific Vocabulary for the Oral History Collection at The National WWII Museum." The Oral History Review 40, no. 1 (2013): 126-34. b. Chew, R. "Collected stories - The rise of oral history in museum exhibitions." Museum News 81, no. 6 (Nov. & dec. 2002): 30-37.   3. Oral Histories II  With audio and written records readily made, how do we put them in the museum setting? This lecture discusses various possibilities and gets students to develop the rationale of their selections through debates and discussions.  Reading: a. Jones, Sian. "Oral History and Museum Education." Oral History 12, no. 2 (October 1, 1984): 68-71. b. Green, Anna. "Returning History to the Community: Oral History in a Museum Setting." The Oral History Review 24, no. 2 (December 1, 1997): 53-72. 4. Sound I: Installation of Performance If the intangible cultural heritage is something as abstract as live performance, the elements of living people inputs are unavoidable. The practices and theories regarding the staging of a live show in the museum setting are hinged on the issue of authenticity. How much control does a curator have over the accuracy of the performance?  Reading: a. Pollock, Della, ed. Exceptional spaces: essays in performance and history (Chapter 1&2). Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 1998. b. Niblett, Hannah; Allison, Jennifer. "Performance as interpretation: a museum studies perspective." Research in Drama Education: The Journal of Applied Theatre and Performance 21, no. 4 (October 1, 2016): 574-80. c. Cox, Michelle A. "Intermedial museum performance: a reflection on the use of intermedial performance as a medium of immersion at the Barbados Museum & Historical Society." Research in Drama Education: The Journal of Applied Theatre and Performance 21, no. 3 (July 2, 2016): 349-54. 5. Sound II: Installation of Music  Musical instruments are valuable museum objects, because they embodied the appreciation of music and the meticulous knowledge in physics and mathematics too. In a gallery as quiet as in a museum, how do we deliver or reconstruct ‘music’ for present-day enjoyment?  Readings: Gillespie, Kirsty. "Musical Landscapes of Lihir: Exploring performance and place in a museum exhibition." Perfect Beat 17, no. 1 (2016): 9-24. PART II Auxiliary devices 6. Use of Videos  Showing a clip in the middle of the exhibition is a common practice. What are the conventions in so doing? What are the advantages and limits of applying animations and other digital devices?  Reading: a. George, Judith; Stevenson, Anne. "Structured video recall: a museum application." British Journal of Educational Technology 22, no. 3 (September 1991): 203-09. b. Bakken, Sven Magne ; Pierroux, Palmyre. "Framing a topic: Mobile video tasks in museum learning." Learning, Culture and Social Interaction 5 (June 2015): 54-65. 7. Use of Dioramas  Dioramas are most useful in the area of Natural Science, because the extinguished animals and plants are best represented through live reconstructions. Historical museums often employ diorama to highlight the visiting experience.  Reading: a. Knutson, Karen; Lyon, Mandela ; Crowley, Kevin ; Giarratani, Lauren. "Flexible Interventions to Increase Family Engagement at Natural History Museum Dioramas." Curator: The Museum Journal 59, no. 4 (October 2016): 339-52. b. Gambini, Annastella ; Pezzotti, Antonella ; Broglia, Alfredo ; Poli, Annamaria. " The Digital Diorama Project: The Design." Procedia - Social and Behavioral Sciences 182 (May 13, 2015): 470-76. 8. Use of Miscellaneous Objects  Not all objects are substantial or significant enough to be regarded as attractive. In fact, a number of museums nowadays are overflowed with objects of low historical values. How may we put them up in the gallery to complete the storyline, while not violating the boundary of over-interpretation?  Readings Hess, M.; Robson, S. The ‘Branch’ Strategy  Gugong (The Palace Museum) is going to set up a branch in Hong Kong. The branch strategy, however, is not a new thing. It began in the 1980s, when a number of century-old museums considered expansion and revenue-raising. This lecture reviews the many successful and unsuccessful cases in the past. What may be the risks for the new branch of Gugong in Hong Kong?  Readings: a. Sai Hua. " Analysis of the impact of the major museums in Asia." Culturas 2, no. 2 (November 1, 2015): 49-68. b. We will test the usefulness of the training package as suggested by ICOM and reflect on its rationale to run the museum as incorporation.  UNESCO Running a Museum: A Practical Handbook, available online. 11. Training II: museum non-curatorial workers Curators are usually not the first person a visitor sees or gets in touch with in the museum. There are receptionists, volunteers, security guards, caretakers, cafe waiters, etc. These people are parts of the museum. Together their bonding represents the brand of the museum. This lecture will again use the ICOM package and check the training programmes suggested in there. UNESCO Running a Museum: A Practical Handbook, available online. 12. Museum Facilities  Cloakrooms, washrooms, disabled facilities, restaurants, and rest areas are essential in a museum nowadays. There is also the space outside the museum building. title: Special Topics in Heritage Management
description: Cultural institutions such as museums, archives, and cultural centers play a critical role in the preservation, interpretation, and dissemination of heritage. Through diverse programs, place-making projects, and cultural policies, these institutions preserve and represent cultural memory, sustain community identity and continuity, and emphasize the importance of community involvement and participatory approaches. They ensure that both tangible and intangible heritage are accessible to the public and future generations. Additionally, they intersect with contemporary issues such as the impact of globalization, tourism, the role of policy-making and advocacy in heritage protection, and the influence of the digital age on cultural heritage.This course aims to provide students with both analytical and practical skills in managing cultural heritage, with a particular emphasis on intangible heritage, which includes oral histories, performative rituals, social practices, and craftsmanship. Students will engage with diverse topics, exploring how the principles and practices of heritage management inform a variety of theories and approaches, such as cultural relativism, ethnocentrism, and post-colonial theory. By focusing on a chosen area of cultural heritage or a particular field of heritage theory, this course will equip students with the ability to reflect on the challenges and opportunities presented by historical and current phenomena and to participate in projects with the potential to impact individuals and societies.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to: Explain key historical and contemporary examples of cultural heritage projects, relating them to broader local and global contexts. Examine critical issues concerning the ways different methods of preservation, interpretation, and dissemination of heritage adopted by cultural institutions. Develop skills to critically analyze intangible heritage, including oral histories, performative rituals, social practices, and craftsmanship. Acquire personal and social competencies related to various forms of culture and become an active agent in managing cultural heritage. Foster an attitude of innovation and creativity by challenging assumptions within existing methods of preservation, interpretation, and dissemination of heritage.

title: Special Topics in Curation
description: Curating in art and culture involves selecting and organizing artworks, cultural artifacts, practices, and narratives to create a cohesive exhibition that conveys a specific theme. This requires a deep understanding of the artists' intentions, the works' context, and diverse cultural expressions, as well as a commitment to preserving heritage and promoting dialogue. Curators play a crucial role in ensuring representation, authenticity, and inclusivity in the audience's experience. In recent years, the concept of curating has extended to social media, where it involves strategically choosing and presenting content to engage a digital audience. This includes managing visuals, texts, and interactive elements to create a compelling online presence. The term "curating," once limited to museums, now applies broadly, reflecting the growing importance of thoughtful content curation in effectively engaging and informing diverse audiences across various platforms. This course aims to provide students with both analytical and practical skills in curation. Students will engage with diverse topics, exploring how various platforms offer unique opportunities for curators to select, organize, manage, and create artworks, artifacts, content, and knowledge. By covering various curatorial strategies in the ever-expanding field of knowledge production, this course will equip students with the ability to reflect on current phenomena and curate projects that have the potential to impact individuals and societies.

title: Special Topics in Cultural Institutions
description: Cultural institutions are organizations that preserve, promote, and disseminate culture, knowledge, and heritage. These institutions can take various forms, ranging from museums, libraries, archives, and galleries to virtual and tech-based platforms. The evolution of cultural institutions reflects broader changes in cultural management models and organizational modes, influenced by ever-changing technology and societal shifts. From traditional museums, libraries, and archives to innovative digital and participatory models, cultural institutions are increasingly leveraging diverse approaches to enhance accessibility, engagement, and cultural impact.This course aims to provide students with both analytical and practical skills in managing cultural institutions. Students will engage with diverse topics, exploring how various models and organizational modes within different types of cultural institutions inform a variety of theories and practices. By focusing on a chosen institutional form or specific field of cultural institutions, this course will equip students with the ability to reflect on current phenomena and participate in projects that have the potential to impact individuals and societies.

title: Special Topic in Creative Industries
description: In recent years, the rapid development of cultural and creative industries has transformed the way cultural products are created, produced and distributed. These industries, from theater and fashion to social media and game design, highlight how contemporary societies use intellectual and creative approaches to gain economic and symbolic competitiveness. Alongside technological innovations, the creative sector also plays a significant role in driving global economic transformation, offering government agencies and entrepreneurs new strategies to produce creative experiences not anticipated in the past.This course aims to provide students with both analytical and practical skills in cultural and creative industries. Students will engage with a diverse range of topics, exploring how various sectors within these industries inform a variety of theories and practices. By covering multiple creative and entrepreneurial strategies in the ever-expanding field of cultural and creative industries, this course will equip students with the ability to reflect on the current phenomenon and create projects that have the potential to impact individuals and societies.
outcome: Explain key historical and contemporary examples of creative industries, relating them to a broader local and global context Examine critical issues concerning how different cultural and economic models impact the creative industries Develop skills to critically analyze the relationship between culture, society and the economy Acquire personal and social competencies relating to the creative industries, and act as an active agent in producing creative projects Develop an attitude of innovation and creativity by challenging assumptions within the creative industries

title: Introduction to Cultural Studies

Concepts such as multiculturalism, diaspora, hybridity, globalism/localism, transnationalism will be discussed. Emphasis will be given to Hong Kong culture as a basic reference point in its contact and interaction with other cultures.

title: Introduction to Film and Screen Studies
description: This course focuses on the language and the basic theories of film/media. From formal, historical and theoretical approaches, students will learn how to analyze and critique the meaning behind the cinematic images; also, will learn to integrate one’s cinematic experience in terms of emotion and reason, and to develop one’s ability in film criticism writing. In the course of teaching, three aspects will be highlighted including the critical, functional and practical ones.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:  - identify, describe, and analyze the technical aspects of film as art.  - deeply analyze in diverse ways of critical thinking on film/media, such as the views of genre, auteurship, and spectatorship, and grasp the ways to utilize these different analytical frameworks for the writing of film criticism.

title: Special Topics in Cultural Studies
description: The specific topics of this course vary from year to year. Generally, they can be genres, systems of representation, cultural forms, issues and/or theories related to the dynamic process of interactivity among cultures. Students are allowed to take this course not more than twice, and gain the units each time they pass the course.
outcome: 1) Students are expected to develop interdisciplinary perspectives to understand and be critical of the following: Our regional, national, and global orders are made up of and maintained by cultural practices, expressions, and meanings. Cultural industries and institutions play a key role to shape our collective identity, taste, and values.  2) Students are expected to develop the following skills and values: Ability in critically analyzing the diversity of values and interests in society Ability in drawing on a number of disciplinary origins within areas of the arts, humanities and social sciences to appreciate the richness and the usefulness of interdisciplinary approach Critical awareness related to issues pertaining to gender, class, and national identities

title: Global Cultural Theories
description: The course will be an introduction to the critical discourses of cultural studies. It aims to provide students with a basic theoretical framework to the understanding and practising of cultural criticisms in contemporary society. The course will outline the theoretical propositions of major thinkers contributing to cultural studies of the last century including those of the Birmingham School, the New Left, the Frankfurt School, the psychoanalysis school, the postmodernists and poststructuralists, etc. Students will be exposed to selected classical writings of major thinkers and learn the questions and methodologies employed by them. The course will equip students with the basic knowledge and concepts in analysing the main issues and practices in cultural studies.
outcome: The objectives are: 1) to get you acquaintance with a range of theoretical approaches that you tend to come across in Cultural Studies; 2) to understand key concepts and contexts of these approaches as well as their unity and diversity; 3) to identify hotspots and issues in contemporary cultural theories for further research or following up; 4) to cultivate your confidence in making use of a broader range of theories as analytical and critical tools in Cultural Studies.

title: Islam: Religious Tradition and Modern Politics
description: This course investigates the complicated relationship between ages-old Islamic tradition and modernity as exemplified most by the rise of secular politics. We will first focus on this problematic by tracing a particular set of questions through which knowledge about Islam and Muslim politics has been produced. By reading excerpts from scholarly works and influential media outlets, by watching documentaries, and through discussions during the class, we will develop a framework in which to recognize, understand and appreciate the gamut of political predicaments that Islamic tradition and its practitioners face under modern conditions. By the end of the first half of this course, students are expected to develop the ability to engage the following questions: What kind of assumptions about Islam and politics inform popular discussions on this topic? How has the rise of modern state power shaped and reshaped Muslims’ understanding of their tradition? What forms of lives, histories and struggles can and cannot be captured by this problematic? We will then spend the last several weeks exploring case studies that are considered to be paradigmatic of Islamic politics today. We will look at such historical and contemporary controversies as the Iraq War, the Arab Spring, the rise of ISIS, and the Jamal Khashoggi affair. In each given case, we will trace various ways in which the questions we addressed in the first half of the course continue to inhabit the narratives about how a supposedly “authentic” Islam figures in Muslims’ search for political and cultural legitimacy in modern times. Thus, the course does not aim so much to provide a survey of Muslims politics, but to develop a critical perspective on the key concepts and images that frame Muslims’ and non-Muslims’ discussions about the convergence between Islam and modern politics.

title: Religious Fundamentalism and Asian Cultures
description: This course aims to introduce the effects of religious fundamentalism on the politics of representation among various Asian cultures. Constituted by peoples of a great variety of ethnicities and languages, national and cultural identities have remained problematic in most countries in Asia. This course will guide students to think through how religious fundamentalism contributes to the making of community identities and its (sometimes militant) politics of difference in Asia. Topics of discussion will include issues of national and ethnic myths, language and religious identities, and the cultural representation of Islamic, Hindu and Christian fundamentalism, etc. in Asia.

title: Religion, Health and Healing
description: Religious traditions contain particular understandings of body and mind, health and wholeness, illness and suffering, healing and transformation. This course will cover the latest discussion on the relationship among religion, health and healing. Also, it will explore the health/healing beliefs and practices in different religious traditions such as Taoism, Judaism, Christianity, Muslim, and New Age Movement, as well as will contrast those beliefs and practices with the hegemony of secular western biomedicine. The central goal of the course will bring students to understand how religious health/healing practices are constructed and experienced as meaningful in today's rapidly changing and globalized world.
